questions.text: A 14-year-old boy sustained an injury to the face during a fight at school. A facial examination revealed a small subcutaneous ecchymosis in the left lower eyelid. An X-ray was performed which is shown in the image below.  What is the sign seen on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a teardrop sign which is characteristic of an orbital floor fracture.

It is also known as a blowout fracture and results in the herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos

Other options:

Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in a CT scan of the glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Option C: Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tympanicum when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Options D: Antral or Holman Miller sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is pathognomic of angiofibroma.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text:
An elderly woman was brought with worsening memory for the past 4 years. Recently she has been unable to carry out her daily chores and got lost at the supermarket. There is no evidence of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following are the main neurotransmitters involved in this condition?
  1. Glutamate
  2. Acetylcholine
  3. Norepinephrine
  4. GABA
  5. Dopamine
questions.solution:
The clinical stem is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. Among the given options, the neurotransmitters that are most often implicated in its pathogenesis are acetylcholine and norepinephrine.

Main neurotransmitters involved:

  • Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert- Reduced acetylcholine
  • Degeneration of the locus coeruleus - Reduced norepinephrine
  • Degeneration of dorsal raphe -Reduced serotonin

Two other neurotransmitters implicated in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease are somatostatin and corticotropin, whose levels are decreased.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. It begins with memory impairment which later progresses to language and visuospatial deficits. Later, the patient has difficulty in keeping track of finances, following instructions, driving, shopping, and housekeeping. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.

Language deficits appear as impairment in naming, comprehension, and finally fluency. Visuospatial defects include difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock. Risk factors for the development of Alzheimer's disease include:

  • Age >70 years
  • Positive family history
  • Female gender
  • Apo ε4 allele
  • Diabetes (increase the risk threefold)
  • Hypertension
  • Elevated homocysteine and cholesterol levels
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, and red wine
  • Low levels of exercise
  • Down syndrome
  • Mutation in presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 genes

Protective factors are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and Apo ε2. 

Treatment: Cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man who developed rhinocerebral mucormycosis post-COVID-19 infection was prescribed amphotericin B. All of the following are the rationales behind choosing liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate for the treatment of this patient, except?

choices.text: Better CNS penetration than amphotericin deoxycholate
Amphotericin deoxycholate needs to be infused at higher rates

questions.solution:
Amphotericin deoxycholate is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of mucormycosis but the rationales behind the usage of liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate in mucormycosis are:

  • Less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate
  • Better CNS penetration than amphotericin B deoxycholate or amphotericin B lipid complex
  • Better outcomes than with amphotericin B deoxycholate 

Liposomal amphotericin B is given in the dose of 5 - 10 mg/kg once per day; 10mg/kg is given in case of CNS infection. Liposomal amphotericin B is more commonly used in the treatment of mucormycosis, than the other conventional formulations of amphotericin B, provided it is readily available.

Infusion-related adverse events are commonly seen with amphotericin B and it has been nicknamed "shake and bake" due to the associated chills and fever. 

Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions cause more infusion-related reactions than conventional amphotericin B. Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB) and Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) have a lesser incidence of infusion reactions than C-AMB. L-AMB may cause slightly lesser infusion-related reactions, and can be infused at higher rates than amphotericin deoxycholate.

Amphotericin B acts by extracting ergosterol from the fungal cell membrane, disrupting the structure and leading to fungal cell death.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl who was on her way home from school was sexually assaulted. On inquiry, it was revealed that three people were involved in the rape. Which of the following is true about this offence?

choices.text: This offence is defined under section 376C
Bruises may not be noticed for 48 hours following the assault
Guarded gait is when the victim walks with legs together and slow paces
The doctor cannot examine her without informing the authorities first

questions.solution:
This incident can be considered as gang rape on a woman under sixteen years of age for which when found guilty, punishment is rigorous imprisonment for life and with fine. During the examination of a rape victim, it is important to consider that bruises may not be noticed for 48 hours following the assault.

This offense is defined under section 376DA of the Indian Penal Code. The type of offence is cognizable and non-bailable. (Option A)

The following is an outline of a planned procedure :

  • The victim should be examined when there is a requisition from investigating police officer or the Magistrate. The victim of rape may go directly to the doctor, who should examine her after obtaining her consent, and after examination he should inform the concerned police station, so that the due legal process can be set in motion. The Court or the police has no power of forcing a woman for medical examination against her will. (Option D)
  • A detailed account of the events and the number of people involved along with the sequence of events are recorded in writing in verbatim.
  • Emotional and mental state of the victim is observed as well.
  • The gait should be observed; whether she complains of pain on walking, on micturition or defaecation. The pain leads to a guarded gait, the victim walking with legs apart and slow paces. (Option C)

Examination proper :

It is followed in the following sequence :

  1. Clothes - The state of clothes and any evidence that they may carry.
  2. General examination: The woman is examined for traces of semen, abrasions, lacerations, and other similar injuries. They are all documented using photographs. It is important to consider that bruises may not be noticed for 48 hours following the assault.
  3. Hair: Both pubic hair and hair from the scalp are taken for samples and any foreign hair if noticed and sealed for further examination as well.
  4. Seminal stains: Swabs are taken from the reproductive tract and the surrounding regions or wherever dried seminal stains are found
  5. Bloodstains: The presence or absence of blood stains are noted. Profuse bleeding may wash out spermatozoa
  6. Venereal disease: The presence of any genital lesions are noted and the general cleanliness of the victim is assessed. 
  7. Local examination of the genitals.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil are suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of megaloblastic anaemia. 

Peripheral smear findings in megaloblastic anaemia:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A child with severe mental retardation was found to have a total absence of myelin in the central nervous system. Laboratory investigations reveal the accumulation of galactosylceramide. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Krabbe’s disease and the enzyme deficient in this disease is β-galactosidase. 

Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. Krabbe’s disease is an autosomal-recessive sphingolipidosis. It is a neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency in β-galactosidase.

Galactosylceramide is the main content in a myelin sheath. It is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells by galactosylation of ceramide. It is broken down by the enzyme β-galactosidase, a lysosomal hydrolase.

In Krabbe’s disease due to deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). This results in the destruction of oligodendroglia and hence total loss of myelin in the central nervous system.

The image given below shows globoid cells seen in Krabbe's disease.

It is characterized by mental retardation, irritability, tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation, seizures, hypertonia, and later flaccidity. Optic atrophy is also present. Investigations reveal increased protein in the CSF.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been found to be effective as a treatment modality for Krabbe's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B has high levels of serum HBeAg. Which of the following viral genes is involved in coding the same?
questions.solution:
HBeAg is coded by the C gene. The presence of high levels of HBeAg (and HBV DNA) suggests high infectivity. 

HBV Genome has four overlapping genes. They code for: 

  • S gene-It codes for surface antigen. 
  • C gene-
    • When the C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed.
    • When translation begins from Pre C region, HBeAg is formed.
  • P gene- Codes for DNA polymerase.
  • X gene- Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic because she is feeling excessively tired these days. She is unable to carry out her day-to-day household works. She says that for the past few months she is having excessive and very frequent menstrual bleeding. On examination, she appears pale, with a smooth tongue. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of iron deficiency anemia due to excessive menstrual bleeding. Serum ferritin is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body.

The majority of the patients with iron deficiency anemia present with easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and dyspnea on exertion. Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes like

  • smooth tongue
  • brittle nails
  • koilonychia- spooning of nails
  • cheilosis- fissures at the corner of the mouth
  • pica- craving for specific foods that are not rich in iron.

Laboratory investigation of iron deficiency anemia

The peripheral smear will show small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) cells with an increased area of central pallor. Pencil-shaped cells can be seen which is called poikilocytosis.

Serum iron levels- It represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The normal range for the serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL. It is decreased in iron deficiency anemia.

Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)- It is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal levels are 300–360 μg/dL. The levels are increased in IDA.

Transferrin saturation- The normal levels are 25–50%. The levels are decreased in IDA.

Serum ferritin- Free iron is toxic to the body. Therefore it is bound to a protein called apoferritin to form ferritin. Adult males have serum ferritin values averaging 100 μg/L, while adult females have levels averaging 30 μg/L. The serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. It is decreased in IDA.

Evaluation of bone marrow iron stores- can be done by performing bone marrow biopsy and using the Prussian stain to stain the iron stores. It is rarely done these days due to the availability of the serum ferritin estimation tests.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 3 days. His stools were greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child having loose greasy, foul-smelling stools, vomiting, and abdominal pain along with stool examination showing trophozoites that are tennis-racquet shaped is strongly suggestive of Giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Infection is common in children and occurs through the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. A single cyst can hatch out into two trophozoites, which eventually colonize the duodenum and upper part of the jejunum. It is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the small intestine in humans.

Clinical features include diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, belching, flatus, nausea, and vomiting which last for more than one week.

Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite that is shaped like a tennis racket and is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped. Trophozoites are convex dorsally and have a sucking disk ventrally, that helps in attachment to the intestinal mucosa. Other tests include the string test/entero test, and serodiagnosis by ELISA kits to detect Giardia-specific antigen, GSA 65.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Other options :

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery. Microscopic examination of a saline wet mount of the stool shows the presence of diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile crystals called Charcot-Leyden crystals along with nuclear masses called pyknotic bodies. Cysts are spherical in shape with a single nucleus while trophozoites have an irregular shape with the presence of pseudopodia. An image of the cyst is shown below.

Option C: Cryptosporidium parvum has the sporulated oocyst as the infective form. The oocyst is acid-fast. Humans are infected by ingestion of contaminated food and water with feces or autoinfection. The patient may be asymptomatic or cause a self-limiting febrile illness, with watery diarrhea in conjunction with abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss.

Option D: Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan, present in the large intestine, infective form is a binucleate cyst. Clinical manifestations - infection is usually asymptomatic, patient rarely develops intermittent diarrhoea and abdominal cramps.  Diagnosis is by stool microscopy. An image of the trophozoite is shown below.

questions.text:
The suture application shown in the given image will be most useful in the management of which of the following conditions?

(PPH- Postpartum hemorrhage)

choices.text: PPH caused due to  HELLP syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a B-lynch suture. It is most useful in the management of PPH caused due to polyhydramnios.

It is a technique to control severe atonic postpartum hemorrhage, which can occur as a result of polyhydramnios. B-lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which oppose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

Predisposing factors for PPH are:

  • Atonic PPH:
    • Grand multipara
    • Previous history of PPH
    • Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia
    • Precipitate labor, prolonged labor
    • Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
    • Labor induction or augmentation with oxytocin
    • Placental anomalies: Placenta previa/ accreta/ increta/ percreta/ abruptio placenta
  • Traumatic PPH:
    • Instrumental deliveries
    • Episiotomy
  • PPH due to Coagulopathy:
    • Sepsis
    • IUD
    • HELLP syndrome

For PPH due to Coagulopathy - transfusion of blood products such as Fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, platelet concenterate is given.

questions.text: What is the use of this surgical instrument?

choices.text: Dilate the punctum of lacrimal gland
Curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora

questions.solution:
The given image shows Bowman's lacrimal probe.  It is identified by the ends of the lacrimal probe which are blunt with a central stable platform. It is used to probe the lacrimal sac in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is also used to identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

Other common instruments used in lacrimal gland surgeries:

Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator (shown in the image attached below) is used to dilate the punctum before lacrimal sac surgeries (Option-C)

 

Lacrimal gland cannula is used for syringing the lacrimal gland and the passage. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. (Option-A)

 

Lacrimal sac curette is used to curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora (Option-D). It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted.

questions.text: Which of the following committees is responsible for establishing the Medical and Health Education Commission?
questions.solution:
The Shrivastav committee recommended the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission for planning and implementing the reforms needed in health and medical education on the lines of the University Grants Commission.

The Shrivastav Committee was formed in the year 1975 as a “group on medical education and support manpower”. The committee was established for the following purposes:

  • To devise a suitable curriculum for training a cadre of health assistants so that they can serve as a link between qualified medical practitioners and multipurpose workers
  • To suggest steps for improving the existing medical educational processes so as to provide due emphasis on the problems particularly relevant to national requirements

The group recommended immediate action for the following: 

  • Creation of bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers from within the community itself (e.g., school teachers, postmasters, gram-sevaks) to provide simple, promotive, preventive, and curative health services needed by the community
  • Establishment of 2 cadres of health workers, namely multipurpose health workers and health assistants, between the community-level workers and doctors at the PHC
  • ROME scheme- Reorientation of Health Education

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated following a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is seen that the patient's speech is fluent; he is able to understand what is said, but unable to repeat simple phrases. Naming of objects is also impaired. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is conduction aphasia.

Conduction aphasia is a form of aphasia in which both fluency and comprehension remain intact, but the patient shows an isolated impairment in their ability to repeat simple phrases and naming of objects. It occurs due to an injury in the dorsal perisylvian region, which connects Broca’s area with Wernicke’s area.

Other options: 

Option B: Wernicke's area lies in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It is an important area for word and sentence comprehension. Damage to this area or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia. It is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired to the spoken and written words or sentences. The speech is fluent, but contains jargon and neologisms. Therefore, the examiner cannot understand what the patient is speaking. 

Option C: Anomic aphasia is a very mild dysfunction of the language network. Comprehension and repetition are intact, but naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. It is due to a lesion within the left hemisphere, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri. It can occur due to head trauma, metabolic encephalopathy, and Alzheimer’s disease.

Option D: In Broca's aphasia, the speech is non-fluent, with impaired repetition and naming. However, comprehension is preserved. Broca's area lies in the inferior frontal gyrus. Injury to this area or occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery leads to Broca's aphasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Serum lactate >5 mmol/L is an indication for damage control surgery.

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical:

  • Inability to achieve hemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid, and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

3 Phases  :

Phase I (Initial Exploration) -

This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.

Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -

This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis.

Phase III (Definitive Operation) -

It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

 

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

questions.text: A child who has been saved from a human trafficking ring has been subjected to a medical examination. The child has no recollection of his identity. His age is estimated to be around 14 years. Which of the following bones from this x-ray help in confirmation of this child's age?
questions.solution:
From the given x-ray, the first metacarpal and pisiform help in confirming this child's age. The child's age is estimated to be between 12 to 17 years. 

In the x-ray photograph of the wrist and hand, the lower epiphyses of the first metacarpals are not united with the shaft. The epiphyses of the metacarpal bones fuse with the shaft between the age of 15 to 17 years. The pisiform has ossified. This makes the minimum age of the child to be 12 years. Hence, the child's age will be between 12 and 17 years.

Hence, the pisiform and metacarpals help in estimating the age of the child in this case. 

Ossification centres of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 1–3 months
  • Hamate:  2–4 months
  • Triquetral: 2–3 years
  • Lunate: 3–4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4–6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5–6 years
  • Pisiform: 10–12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18–19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5–6 years of age and fuses at 17–18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18 years.

questions.text: What is the procedure of choice for the following condition in an elderly female?
questions.solution:
The given image shows eversion of lower lid margin in an aged female with visible fornix. It is suggestive of lower lid severe senile ectropion and the surgical treatment of choice is Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation.

In this surgery, a base up pentagonal full-thickness excision from the lateral third of the eyelid is combined with triangular excision of the skin from the area just lateral to lateral canthus to elevate the lid. 

As a temporary method, taping of the sagging lid can be done

The first image below depicts the important components of this surgery. The second image depicts the taping method. The last image shows the components of medial conjunctivoplasty.

Ectropion: Out rolling or outward turning of the lid margin.

Etiological types:

  1. Congenital ectropion: Common in Downs syndrome.
  2. Involutional/Senile ectropion: Age-related laxity of either medial canthus tendon, lateral canthus tendon or horizontal lower lid. It can sometimes be associated with disinsertion of  lower lid retractors.'
  3. Cicatricial ectropion: Scarring associated with chemical, thermal or lacerating injuries.
  4. Paralytic ectropion: Due to paralysis of the seventh cranial nerve secondary to infections of the middle ear or iatrogenic during parotid surgery.
  5. Mechanical ectropion: Due to lower lid tumours or proptosis.

Clinical features:

  • The most consistent symptom is epiphora.
  • Rarely associated with photophobia and discomfort.

Signs:

Snap test: Lid can be easily pulled away from the globe but fails to snap back to the normal position on release.

Depending upon the degree of outrolling, ectropion can be divided into three grades:

  • Grade I: The punctum is everted.
  • Grade II: Lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible.
  • Grade III: The fornix is also visible

Treatment of senile ectropion:

  • Medial conjunctivoplasty: It is useful in mild cases of ectropion involving punctal area.
  • Byron Smith’s modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation
  • Horizontal lid shortening
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique

Note:

Weis operation (Transverse lid split and everting sutures), Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones procedure), Quickert's procedure (horizontal lid laxity in entropion), Anterior lamellar resection and Tarsal wedge resection are the surgical procedures employed in the correction of entropion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted after testing positive for COVID-19. He has no known comorbidities. On admission, his blood glucose(BG) levels are recorded as follows. : Fasting BG : 184 mg/dl; post-prandial BG : 302 mg/dl. It has been decided to start him on a basal-bolus insulin regimen. What is the total daily dose of insulin required for this patient? (Weight = 60 kgs)
questions.solution:
This patient requires 12 units of insulin per day.

The following is followed for initiation of insulin for newly diagnosed diabetes patients with COVID-19 infection :

Indication: At admission: pre-meal BG: ≥180 mg/dl or post-meal BG ≥250 mg/dl

A. Total daily dose (TDD) = 0.4 units/kg/day (age > 65 yr, nephropathy or liver disease, use 0.2 units/kg/day)

In this scenario where the patient is 68 years old, 0.2 units/kg/day is administered.

TDD = 0.2 x 60 = 12 units/day

B. The Total daily dose is divided equally into 4 doses (25% each): 3 doses are for bolus insulin (Regular insulin 30 min before breakfast, before lunch, and before dinner) and 1 dose for basal insulin (Inj. NPH insulin at bed time/ 2 hours after dinner)

This is the initial insulin regimen to be prescribed.

questions.text: The structure marked "?" in the image is composed of _____ cartilage.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" in the image is the thyroid cartilage, and it is composed of hyaline cartilage.

Thyroid cartilage is identified by the presence of superior and inferior horns, and its relation with the epiglottis and larynx. The given image shows a cut-open view of the larynx from the back, and here, the thyroid cartilage encases the larynx anteriorly. The stalk of the epiglottis is also seen attached to the inner surface of the thyroid cartilage.

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix:

  • The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in groups of eight that originate from the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan), and chondronectin (glycoprotein).
  • The matrix that immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix, whereas the matrix that is more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

Hyaline cartilage is found at various sites:

  • Larger respiratory passages (nose, larynx, trachea, and bronchi)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Base of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Ventral end of ribs, where they articulate with the sternum
  • Epiphyseal plate of long bones
  • Articular cartilage of synovial joints 
  • Temporary skeleton in embryo

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by the following characteristics:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes, which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

questions.text: You are tasked with holding a public service announcement about the benefits of getting vaccinated, at a small town of farmers. You want to deliver some statistical data to encourage vaccination. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to uneducated populations or people who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Once collected, statistical data must be arranged such that the relevant points are clearly presented. The various tools used to depict statistical data include tables, charts, diagrams, graphs, and pictures.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the transcription process. The sequence of the RNA he produced from a fragment of DNA is CAAGGU. Which one of the following will be the sequence of the coding strand in the DNA that gave rise to this sequence?
questions.solution:
The sequence of the coding strand in the DNA will be CAAGGT.

The non-template strand or coding strand in the DNA will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of CAAGGU would correspond to a DNA sequence, on the non-template strand, of CAAGGT.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be GTTCCA (written 5′ to 3′).

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in front of the neck as shown in the image. On examination, it is a well-defined smooth midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. The swelling was surgically removed and histopathological examination of the specimen showed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most common variant of carcinoma likely to be seen in such cases?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image given are suggestive of the thyroglossal cyst and papillary carcinoma is the most common type of cancer (seen in 85% cases) found in thyroglossal cysts.

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion, and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children they may also present in adults, even as late as the 6th or 7th decade.

Complications:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts

Treatment:

Sistrunk’s operation

Excision of the cyst along and the whole thyroglossal tract up to the foramen caecum along with the removal of the body of the hyoid bone. This is essential to avoid recurrence of the sinuses.

Note:

Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is indicated only if a papillary carcinoma is found to arise from the cyst in the setting of : 

  • Lymph node metastasis
  • Thyroid nodularity
  • Cyst wall invasion
  • Large tumors

The image below shows the Sistrunk procedure-

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient, who is a known diabetic, with a history of repeated blood transfusions for thalassemia was admitted to the hospital after acquiring COVID-19 infection. The patient is on deferoxamine for iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions. He also took prophylactic antifungal drugs 2 weeks back for a suspected fungal infection. At present, he is on low-dose steroids. Which of the following drugs will not increase this patient’s susceptibility to develop mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Isuvaconazole will not increase the patient’s susceptibility to develop mucormycosis. All the other three drugs will increase the patient’s susceptibility to develop mucormycosis.

Hyperglycemia induced by steroid use increases the risk of mucormycosis by 4 mechanisms:

  • Hyperglycation of iron- sequestering proteins, disrupting normal iron sequestration.
  • Upregulation of a mammalian cell receptor (GRP78) that binds to Mucorales, enabling tissue penetration (due to both a direct effect of hyperglycemia and increasing levels of free iron, which independently enhances GRP78 expression).
  • Induction of poorly characterized defects in phagocytic function and 
  • Enhanced expression of CotH, a Mucorales-specific protein that mediates host cell invasion by binding to GRP7I (due to hyperglycemia and the resulting free iron).

Deferoxamine, an iron chelator used in iron overload has an increased risk of developing rapidly fatal disseminated mucormycosis. It is an iron chelator for the human host, but it serves as a fungal siderophore, directly delivering iron to the fungus.

Patients who has received anti-fungal prophylaxis with voriconazole or itraconazole may be at increased risk of mucormycosis.  These patients typically presents with disseminated mucormycosis, the most lethal form of disease.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole and isuvaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: What is the frequency at which the post-placement medical examination should be done in an individual whose occupational exposure is related to the symbol shown below?
questions.solution:
The symbol signifies radiation hazard, the post-placement medical examination in radiation industry workers is done at a frequency of once in 2 months or 6 times a year.

  • Daily examination is done for Dichromate exposure
  • Monthly for lead, dye exposure
  • Annual medical examination is done for most other occupational exposures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight loss and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. A barium swallow is performed which shows the following finding. What is the most common site of carcinoma in such patients?
questions.solution:
The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from this condition.

The barium swallow shows an esophagal web, which refers to an esophagal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen, as shown in the image below. Esophageal web is associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

The post-cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina. It is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from Plummer–Vinson syndrome.

Patients are usually asymptomatic, however, if the stenosis is severe, symptoms include dysphagia and regurgitation of food. 

Triad seen in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome:

  • Iron Deficiency Anemia
  • Esophageal webs
  • Dysphagia

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea, fatigue, and altered mental status. Examination reveals a temperature of 101 F. Laboratory investigations show a platelet count of 60,000 cells/cu mm and creatinine levels of 2.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is not likely to be seen on the peripheral smear in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the classical pentad of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). This condition is a cause of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which is seen on the peripheral blood smear and spur cells are not likely to be seen in this case.

Triangle cells, burr cells, helmet cells, and red cell fragments (schistocytes) are seen in blood smears due to intravascular hemolysis following trauma to the red blood cells in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

The other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer

The common pathogenic feature in all these disorders is microvascular lesions due to the deposition of platelets causing luminal narrowing. This lead to shear stress that injures passing RBCs.

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy occurring due to deficiency in the plasma enzyme ADAMTS13  also known as vWF metalloprotease. Normally, ADAMTS13 cleaves multimers of vWF but in its absence, the large multimers accumulate in plasma thereby causing platelet activation and aggregation spontaneously. This leads to clinical manifestations.

The manifestations are fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, neurologic deficits, and renal failure.

Triangle cells are small red cells fragments of varying shapes with sharp angles or spines with a dark or pale center. Echinocytes or Burr cells are the pathologic red cells that have short and regularly spaced spicules with preserved central pallor. It is seen in uremia, bleeding ulcers, and gastric carcinoma. The image below shows Echinocytes.

Acanthocyte or spur cells are the red cells that have spicules at irregular intervals. The spicules are of varying length and dense center. These are seen in liver disease, abetalipoproteinemia and post splenectomy. The images of acanthocytes are as shown below :

The following image shows helmet cells/schistocytes which are distorted and fragmented cells with two or three pointed ends. They are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgical intervention of tertiary hyperparathyroidism except ____

choices.text: Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland

questions.solution:
Reduced serum phosphate is not an indication for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism. 

Renal transplantation in patients with chronic kidney diseases may be associated with autonomous functioning of the parathyroid gland. This is called tertiary hyperparathyroidism where there is hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism.

The indications for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are as follows :

  • Subacute severe hypercalcaemia (>3 mmol/L)
  • Impaired graft function
  • Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland(s)
  • Progressive symptoms for >2 years following transplantation
    • Worsening bone disease - pain, fractures, bone loss
    • Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis
    • Soft tissue or vascular calcifications

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology department with the following complaint. Which of the following forms the first line of management for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows esotropia (convergent squint),  commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia). The first line of management in the treatment of esotropia includes refractive error correction with glasses. 

In a child with associated accommodation issues and non-compliance to glasses, miotics are generally used. Di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate (Option-A) is commonly used for this condition. Long-term usage causes secondary iris cysts. Prevention of these secondary iris cysts can be achieved by the concomitant use of phenylephrine. So, in such cases, both echothiophate + phenylephrine eye drops are prescribed (Option-B)

Further treatment may include orthoptic training (Option-D) or surgical correction of the squint.

Accommodative esotropia is a common type of squint due to the overaction of convergence associated with accommodation. This overaction is usually to overcome a hyperopic refractive error. It presents at around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types of accommodative esotropia include:

  • Refractive
    • Associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)
    • Fully correctable by spectacles
  • Non-refractive type 
    • Occurs independent of refractive errors
    • A small increase in accommodation is accompanied by a dis­proportionately large increase in convergence
    • Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio
    • Fully corrected by bifocal glasses

Image: Accommodative esotropia with and without correction

Mnemonic

The algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: for remaining error

The given image shows an iris pigment epithelial (IPE) cyst near the pupillary margin seen clinically secondary to echothiophate use.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient comes to the emergency department complaining of high fever, chills, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. Laboratory tests of blood and stool cultures show an oxidase-negative, motile, gram-negative bacillus which is cultured in the media pictured below.  Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism, in this case, is Salmonella typhi. Salmonella is a gram-negative rod that is motile, oxidase negative, and shows large black colonies, with a metallic sheen when cultured in Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulfite to sulfide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. Typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen and S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Other options-

Option A - Shigella can cause bloody diarrhea and present similarly to Salmonella species infection. They also are oxidase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods. However, Shigella species are non-motile, while Salmonella species are motile.

Option B - Escherichia coli (EHEC, EIEC) can cause bloody diarrhea. They are also gram-negative rods that are oxidase-negative. However, E. coli does not produce black colonies in a bismuth sulfite medium.

Option D- Pseudomonas aeruginosa does not cause bloody diarrhea. Although it is a gram-negative bacillus, it is oxidase-positive.

questions.text: Which of the following CT findings is not an indication to perform angiography in a splenic trauma patient under conservative management?
questions.solution:
In a splenic trauma patient under conservative management, angiography is indicated if the CT shows a high-grade injury rather than a low-grade injury (subcapsular hematoma covering 40% surface area is a grade II injury).

In splenic trauma patients that are managed conservatively, angiography is indicated if there is the presence of the following CT findings:

  • Contrast extravasation
  • Presence of pseudoaneurysm
  • Significant hemoperitoneum
  • High-grade injury
  • Evidence of vascular injury

Management of Splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

  • They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively.
  • Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals and serial CECT.
  • If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis.
  • If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable or if there is a contrast blush, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of Grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of Grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries: These patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A patient comes with productive cough with yellow sputum and high-grade fever with chills for the past 4 days. He has increased tactile fremitus, dull notes on percussion of the right side, and crackles. A chest radiograph was performed and is shown below. The doctor uses a criteria to find out if the patient needs hospitalization or not. All of the following are the components of this criteria except:
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, increased tactile fremitus with crackles in the lung fields, and the radiograph indicates a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia. The need for hospitalization in this patient is assessed using the CURB 65 criteria. Consolidation is not a parameter included in this criteria.

CURB 65 scores for community-acquired pneumonia:

Clinical factor Points
Confusion  1
Blood urea nitrogen > 19 mg per dL 1
Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths per minute 1
Systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg or Diastolic blood pressure ≤ 60 mm Hg 1
Age ≥ 65 years 1 

Interpretation:

  • Scores 0-1 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered
  • Score 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
  • Scores 3-5 are severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to intensive care

Another similar criteria used in the assessment of the severity of pneumonia is CRB-65. Here the urea levels in the blood are not considered. The rest of the parameters are the same as those used in CURB-65. In this,

  • Score 0 has a low risk of death and does not require hospitalization
  • Score 1 and 2 have an increased risk of death and hospitalization is considered.
  • Score 3 and 4 have a high risk of death and require urgent hospitalization.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man who sustained trauma to the scrotal area a few days back came to the hospital with sudden onset of pain in the perineal and scrotal area, with blackening of the scrotum, as shown in the image. Which of the following statement is false with respect to this condition?

choices.text: It is usually not a surgical emergency.
Alcoholism is a predisposing factor for this condition.
It occurs due to a mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and image showing black, necrotic skin over an inflamed scrotum indicate that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and it is a surgical emergency. 

Fournier's gangrene is characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissue of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is necrotizing fasciitis with rapid onset gangrene, which leads to the exposure of the scrotal contents.

Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus, and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. It may occur after minor injuries or procedures done in the perineal region.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: a mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene formation

It presents with sudden pain, pyrexia, and prostration. There may be a foul-smelling exudate and crepitus may be present. The testes are usually not affected. Cellulitis spreads and involves the skin and coverings of the scrotum, and penis. This may get sloughed and expose the testes, which remain healthy. It is also referred to as "shameful exposure of the testis." 

It is a surgical emergency.

  • Initial management is by intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Urgent wide surgical excision of dead and infected tissue is essential.

Despite the best therapy, mortality rates have been reported to be as high as 50%.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in labor started bleeding profusely immediately after artificial rupture of membranes and emergency LSCS was performed. The placenta of the patient is given below. Identify the type of placenta.
questions.solution:
The type of placenta shown in the image is the velamentous placenta. The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

The scenario described is suggestive of vasa previa, in which part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

Battledore placenta: The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

Succenturiate placenta: One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

questions.text: A patient with melioidosis was prescribed imipenem. Why was this drug administered along with cilastatin?

choices.text: Cilastatin blocks the hepatic metabolism of imipenem.
Cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.
Imipenem blocks the hepatic metabolism of cilastatin.
Imipenem blocks the renal metabolism of cilastatin.

questions.solution:
Imipenem is administered with cilastatin because cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme dehydropeptidase, which is present in the renal tubules. Therefore, imipenem is administered with cilastatin, an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin inhibits the breakdown and prolongs the action of imipenem. This drug combination is used to treat infections caused by cephalosporin-resistant nosocomial bacteria.

Imipenem is a carbapenem beta-lactam antibiotic. It has a broader spectrum of action than other beta-lactams. It binds to penicillin-binding proteins and disrupts cell wall synthesis, leading to the death of susceptible microorganisms. It is resistant to hydrolysis by most β-lactamases. It is not absorbed orally. The dose should be modified for patients with renal insufficiency.

The FDA approved Recarbrio (a combination of imipenem-cilastatin and relebactam) to treat hospital-acquired bacterial pneumonia and ventilator-associated bacterial pneumonia in patients aged ≥18 years. It was previously approved for the treatment of patients with complicated urinary tract infections and complicated intra-abdominal infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

Note: Melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, resembles glanders disease, which is due to Burkholderia mallei and primarily affects horses, with the potential for transmission to humans. It can present as acute melioidosis, leading to pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates and symptoms similar to tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, and hemoptysis, potentially progressing to septicemia. In its chronic form, it results in caseous or suppurative lesions, skin abscesses, lymphangitis, and lymphadenopathy, and may also impact bones and internal organs.

questions.text: Which of the following prostacyclin analogues can be used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension?
questions.solution:
Iloprost is a prostacyclin analogue indicated in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension. It mimics endogenous prostacyclin. It is an inhaled formulation which causes vasodilation of pulmonary vasculature. 

Side effect includes throat irritation, cough and bronchospasm. Contraindicated in cases of severe hypotension, pulmonary edema due to its vasodilatory properties.

Other prostacyclin analogues are : 

Epoprostenol is also used as a first line drug for severe pulmonary hypertension. It is administration by continuous IV infusion. Major side effects includes jaw pain, hypotension, myalgia, flushing, nausea, vomiting and dizziness. It has a short half-life (3-6 mins)  which requires immediate medical attention to pump failure. 

Treprostinil is used as first-line therapy for pulmonary hypertension due to interstitial lung disease. It is available as IV, SC, inhaled, and oral preparations. It has longer half-life (4 hours) than epoprostenol with same side effects. There's increased risk of bleeding because it inhibit platelet aggregation.

Selexipag is selective PGI2 receptor agonist. It is given as oral formulation. Side effects include headache, jaw pain, nausea, diarrhe. Drug interactions with CYP2C8 inducers/inhibitors. Dose reduction is required in moderate or severe hepatic impairment.

Other option :

Option B : Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor. It is used to treat errectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension.

Option C : Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analog. It is used in NSAIDs induced gastric ulcer, medical abortion, induction of labour, atonic post partum hemorrhage (PPH), cervical ripening.

Option D : Dinoprost is a natural PGF2-alpha preparation. It is used in atonic PPH and induction of 2nd trimester abortion.

NOTE: Dinoprost is natural PGF2-alpha preparation, not to be confused with dinoprostone which is a synthetic analogue of PGE2.

questions.text: A patient developed generalized pruritis and swelling of the face, lips, and tongue after having dinner at a new restaurant. He also complained of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.solution:
This is an example of an IgE-mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. It is also known as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. IgE immunoglobulin is the only heat-labile antibody.

The primary mediators of type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

IgE:

  • Half-life: 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat-labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.
  • It does not pass the placental barrier or fix complement.

  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A young myopic male presents with intermittent haloes.  Gonioscopy reveals an open angle and hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork. Slit-lamp examination is shown below. This finding is called as
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings are suggestive of pigmentary glaucoma. The slit lamp image shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma more common in young myopic males and they usually have hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork and an open-angle on gonioscopy. It occurs due to the blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the pigment particles that are released from rubbing the iris pigment epithelium.

The patients are asymptomatic and usually presents for a routine ophthalmic check-up or may present with intermittent haloes at times. It has the following features:

  • The pigment particles are deposited on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle shape called Krukenberg spindles as seen in slit lamp examination. 
  • Radial transillumination defect on the illumination of the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface of the lens. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.
  • Some patients may exhibit higher levels of IOP(Intraocular pressure) than in POAG. Over time the control of IOP may become easier as pigment liberation decreases and occasionally the IOP may revert to normal. So, it is not always high. 
 

The image shows iris transillumination in the slit-lamp examination, clearly showing a pigmentary defect in the areas of chronic rubbing due to iridolenticular and intraocular lens haptic contact with the posterior face of the iris.

 

Other options:

Option A: Polychromatic lustre or breadcrumb appearance is characteristic of a complicated/secondary cataract which develops secondary to inflammatory and degenerative conditions of the lens of the eye. The given image shows a complicated cataract in a patient with uveitis. 

 

Option B: Aqueous flares occur due to the breakdown in the blood-aqueous barrier, and protein exudates escape into the anterior chamber. It seen in anterior uveitis. The below-given image shows the presence of cells and aqueous flare in a case of anterior uveitis.

 

Option C: Old healing keratic precipitates are seen in the healing stages of uveitis. The earliest sign of anterior uveitis is aqueous flare and the pathognomonic sign is keratic precipitate. The image below shows the slit-lamp photograph showing large old keratic precipitates.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2 V2 M4 when he was brought to the casualty. After a few hours, it became E1 V1 M3. On examination, there are no fractures and no signs of hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. MRI of the patient is shown below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the MRI are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

The given image is an axial T2 -weighted MR image demonstrating numerous foci of diffusion restriction, at the grey-white matter junction denoting petechial hemorrhages. It is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from rotational acceleration.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • Typically located at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, and in more severe cases in the brainstem.
  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI (Susceptibility weighted imaging) or GRE (Gradient echo) sequences demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artefact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum or the brain stem. 

Other options: 

CT showing intraventricular hemorrhage

CT scan showing cerebral contusions, hemorrhage within the hemispheres, and subdural hematoma on the left.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following would favor a diagnosis of Vit B12 deficiency over folic acid deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with lab findings showing high MCV is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. The presence of increased methylmalonyl Co-A favors Vit B12 deficiency. In folic acid deficiency, methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal.

  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules

Option B: If peripheral neuropathy had been present, it woukd have favoured Vit B12 deficiency.

  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. questions.text: An emphysematous patient with a known alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency developed icterus, with mild hepatomegaly and flapping tremors. The liver biopsy findings of this patient are shown below. Which of the following properties correlate with the histopathology staining in this condition?

choices.text: Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive , Diastase - Sensitive
Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive , Diastase - Resistant
Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative , Diastase - Sensitive
Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative , Diastase - Resistant

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant staining properties of the liver histopathology correlate with this condition.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder of protein misfolding that occurs due to a mutation in chromosome 14 and results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. This results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by the presence of round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes, that are strongly Periodic acid–Schiff positive after diastase digestion of the liver, and highlights the characteristic magenta cytoplasmic granules. As a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes, deranged liver enzymes and icterus suggestive of cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma can occur. 

Other uses of PAS include the demonstration of amoeba, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
