questions.text: Which of the values indicated on the given image most likely correspond to the mean, median, and mode, respectively?
questions.solution:
The labelings in the given positively skewed graph indicate mean (3), median (2), and mode (1).

  • Mode - value with the greatest frequency
  • Median - Value that divides the frequency distribution into half when the data is arranged in ascending or descending order
  • Mean - Value that denotes the average of the distribution

The X-axis denotes the values and these correspond as follows:

  1. Negatively (left) skewed: Mean < Median < Mode
  2. Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode
  3. Positively (right) skewed: Mode < Median < Mean

Note:

Median is always in between mode and mean in a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: As the medical officer of a factory, you advise installing a water purification system to treat polluted water which is a by-product of the manufacturing process. The method of water purification is chosen and the blueprint is as shown below. Which of the following is true about this method of purification?

choices.text: Loss of head allowed is 2-2.5 metres
Highly skilled labor is required to operate the filter
Preliminary treatment involves chemical coagulation and sedimentation

questions.solution:
The blueprint depicts a picture of a slow sand filter where bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters up to 99.9-99.99%. Rapid filters clear bacteria up to 98-99%

Slow Sand Filters:

These are also called biological filters. They are accepted as the standard method of large-scale water purification. The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.

Rapid Sand Filters:

They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large-scale purification of water. Two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).

Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:

  • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum, the dose of which varies from 5 to 40 mg or more per liter depending upon color, turbidity, temperature, and pH value of the water.
  • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
  • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. Usually, a mechanical type of flocculator is used which has paddles that rotate at 2 to 4 RPM (rotations per minute) with the help of a motor. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminum hydroxide.
  • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculant along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place. 
  • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
    • Filter beds: Each unit of the filter bed has a surface of about 80 to 90 m2. The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 meter and has graded gravel below it.
    • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer that adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.

Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200m.g.a.d 2-3m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4-0.7mm 0.2-0.3mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation 
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2-2.5m / 6-8feet 1.5m / 4feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good Fair 
Removal of bacteria 98-99% 99.9-99.99% 


The blueprint given below depicts rapid sand filtration

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient with Crohn's disease underwent resection of a segment of the bowel. Following resection, the patient noticed that his stools have become bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and float in the toilet bowl. Which of the following statements is false regarding the resected segment of the bowel?

choices.text: It is the only site of absorption of bile salts
It is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12
Resection of this segment leads to decreased gastric motility
Oral cholestyramine may be required in resections as small as 100cm

questions.solution:
The history of bulky, pale, and floating stools indicates steatorrhea which is seen in ileal resection. Resection of the ileum does not lead to decreased gastric motility.

Small bowel motility is three times slower in the ileum than in the jejunum. In addition, the ileocaecal valve may slow the transit. Resection of the ileum, thus, results in a significant enhancement of gastric motility and acceleration of intestinal transit. This results in increased delivery of fluids and electrolytes to the colon which results in symptoms of diarrhea. 

The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts (Options A & B). Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis. Depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption (steatorrhea). The loss of bile salts into the colon affects the colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Resections as small as 100cm can cause steatorrhoea, which requires the administration of oral cholestyramine to bind the bile salts (Option D). Larger resections may require dietary fat restriction.

questions.text: A newborn baby presented to the pediatrician with respiratory distress.  On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The baby was born via normal vaginal delivery at term and antenatal visits were not done regularly. An X-ray of the infant is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: For small defects a porous polytetrafluoroethylene patch can be used
Extra corporeal membranous oxygenation is contraindicated
Conventional mechanical ventilation is used for managing respiratory failure
Bag and mask ventilation should be used in the initial management

questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with a mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and conventional mechanical ventilation is the main strategy used to support respiratory failure in infants with CDH.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia.  Bochdalek hernia is the most common variant.

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Diaphragmatic eventration
  • Cystic adenomatoid malformation
  • Bronchogenic cyst
  • Cystic teratoma

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fi-O2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient is diagnosed to have athetosis with tremors on one side and oculomotor nerve palsy on the opposite side. A diagnosis of Benedikt's syndrome is made. Damage to which of the following marked structure is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Benedikt's syndrome occurs due to injury to the red nucleus (Nucleus ruber) marked as 1 in the image. It is identified as it is located dorsomedial to the substantia nigra(Locus niger).

2- Thalamus

3- Internal capsule

4- Pons

Red Nucleus:

It is a rounded mass of grey matter located dorsomedial to the substantial nigra. It has a reddish hue in fresh specimens due to its extensive vascularity and the presence of ferric iron pigments in multipolar neurons.

The afferent connections of the red nucleus are from:

  • The cerebral cortex by the corticospinal fibres
  • The cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle
  • The lentiform nucleus, hypothalamic and subthalamic nuclei, substantial nigra, and spinal cord.

Efferent connections of the red nucleus pass to 

  • The spinal cord by the rubrospinal tract
  • The reticular formation through the rubroreticular tract
  • The substantia nigra
  • The thalamus

Clinical correlate:

Injury to the red nucleus can cause Benedikt's syndrome characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral tremors, chorea, and athetosis.

questions.text: A radiograph of a patient with a history of injury to the hand is given below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph showing a fracture of the radial styloid process points to a diagnosis of Chauffeur's fracture.

It is caused either by direct trauma to the wrist or traumatic radial deviation of the wrist.

Option A: Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius with volar subluxation of the wrist.

Option C: Smith's fracture is a distal radial fracture with associated volar angulation of the distal fracture fragment. It is also called reverse Colles fracture. 

Option D: Rolando’s fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: As a 1st-year resident surgeon, you are operating on a 30-year-old patient with unilateral cystic scrotal swelling which is brilliantly transilluminating. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings are suggestive of hydrocele.

Eversion of the sac upon itself is known as Jaboulay's procedure and should be done in this case of hydrocele.

A hydrocele is due to fluid accumulation between the 2 layers of tunica vaginalis. It may be primary or secondary, depending on whether it is due to defective absorption or excess formation. Eversion of the sac causes the production of fluid towards the outside, which can be absorbed by outer scrotal layers.

The other method of treating the hydrocele is plicating the redundant tunica, which can be done when the sac wall is thin. This is known as the Lord's operation.

Other options:

Option A: Excision of the sac is not recommended as it is liable to bleed and cause a scrotal hematoma.

Option C: Ligation of the scrotal vein will impair venous drainage and result in ischemia or oedema.

Option D: Percutaneous drainage of fluid is not a long-term solution as the fluid will reappear within a week. 

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A male infant with a history of not passing meconium was referred to you. On examination, abdominal distension was noted. The findings of barium enema are shown below. You can manage this case surgically by all of the following surgical procedures, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. All the above procedures are used in the surgical management of this case, except Bianchi procedure, which is an intestinal lengthening procedure used in short bowel syndrome. 

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. There is a failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The imaging method of choice for diagnosis of Hirschprung disease is a contrast enema. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is a rectal biopsy. The biopsy specimen shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing: This method is now being widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining in confirming the diagnosis.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum; then, the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: Identify the following device.
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a cock-up splint. It is used to manage radial nerve palsy. 

Radial nerve palsy manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. The cock-up splint is designed to counteract the wrist drop position by holding the wrist in a slightly extended or neutral position, which helps prevent further contracture and allows for functional use of the hand.

Other options:

Option B: Undisplaced Colles' fracture is managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Option C: Knuckle bender splint is used in cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated. The splint can be used to correct and prevent metacarpophalangeal hyperextension by maintaining flexion as shown below.

Option D: Dynamic finger splint can be used for:

  • Immobilization in case of fracture of the proximal phalanx 
  • Extensor tendon injuries of the finger
  • Prevention of deformities in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Post-operative immobilization.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation, lethargy, and has poor activities. Clinical examination reveals jaundice,  hypotonia and there was no palpable goiter. Laboratory investigations revealed a low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is thyroid dysgenesis. History of constipation, lethargy, poor activities, jaundice, and hypotonia is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. Since the child is 4 months of age, this is a case of congenital hypothyroidism. Congenital hypothyroidism with no palpable goiter, low T4, and elevated TSH is suggestive of thyroid dysgenesis. It is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism.

Thyroid dysgenesis is the aplasia, hypoplasia, or an ectopic thyroid gland.

Causes of Congenital hypothyroidism:

         Goitrous

    (Palpable goiter)

     Non-goitrous

   (No palpable goiter)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Thyroid dysgenesis
  • Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies
  • Central hypothyroidism

 

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

 

Laboratory Findings:

Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Present Low Elevated

questions.text: You are following up on a patient who is suspected to have Gradenigo's syndrome. Which of the following will not constitute a component of the classical triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Gradenigo’s Syndrome generally occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. It is a complication of the attico-antral type of otitis media. Immobility of the homolateral soft palate (generally due to X cranial nerve palsy) is not a component of its classical triad of symptoms. 

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy) - lateral rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Fever, headache, vomiting and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated. Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.

Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Note - 

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

This is generally seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension for a year is being evaluated for loin pain. On examination, there is an abdominal mass felt on palpation. A  CT scan was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a CT image showing multiple cysts in both the kidneys points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and hepatic cysts are the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition. 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of renal failure in this disease is faster in males.

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Hematuria
  • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

It is associated with a number of extrarenal manifestations like polycystic liver disease, where cysts are usually asymptomatic but symptoms may occur due to the mass effect of cysts, intracranial berry aneurysms are seen in approximately 10% of patients with ADPKD and mitral valve prolapse, the most common valvular abnormality observed in patients with ADPKD can be diagnosed by echocardiography.

Intravenous pyelography shows a characteristic spider leg pattern, as a result of narrowed and stretched calyces and elongated, compressed renal pelvis. Ultrasonographic diagnostic criteria for individuals at 50% risk for the disease include two unilateral or bilateral cysts in those younger than 30 years of age or two cysts in each kidney for those between 30 and 59 years of age or four cysts in each kidney at ages 60 and over.

Treatment includes management of hypertension using ACE inhibitors like lisinopril or angiotensin receptor blockers like telmisartan. Narcotic analgesics should be limited to episodes of acute pain. V2 receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan have been observed to slow the decline in renal function over a 3 year period.

USG-guided CT aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic; surgical unroofing of multiple or large cysts may alleviate symptoms of pain. Nephrectomy is indicated for symptomatic patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic.  Urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following tissues cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased here is ketone bodies and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxy butyrate. 

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child is brought to the vaccination camp. What would you do?

choices.text: Proceed with the immunization of the child for measles
Give half of the dose of usual vaccination
No vaccination is given as the child is less than 9 months
Give the vaccine only if the child develops symptoms

questions.solution:
In the setting of a measles epidemic, we proceed with immunization of measles for this child.

The scheduled age for receiving the first dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months. The second dose is given between 15 - 18 months of age such that the minimum interval between the 2 doses is 4 weeks.  A supplementary dose can be given at the age of  6 months for the following cases:

  • As a part of intensified service delivery during a measles outbreak 
  • In places where the risk of measles among infants < 9 months of age remains high (endemic countries experiencing regular outbreaks)
  • Individual infants at high risk of contracting measles (history of contact with known cases)
  • Infants traveling to countries experiencing measles outbreaks
  • Infants who are known to be HIV-infected or exposed 

Infants immunized between 6 months should further receive doses 1 and 2 according to the national schedule. Thus in the given case, this infant will be immunized at 6 months due to the epidemic and then receive the regular doses at 9 and 15-18 months of age.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of cough, fever, and fatigue for one week comes to the emergency room with worsening respiratory symptoms. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension and has previously not sought medical care for his condition. Physical examination reveals a patient in distress, with a pulse rate of 110/min, respiratory rate of 42/minute, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation at room air is 80%. RT-PCR for COVID-19 is positive. The patient is placed on NIV but does not respond. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are planned. Which of the following disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) is approved for use in this patient, as per the emergency use authorization by FDA?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette of a patient suffering from severe covid-19 requiring mechanical ventilation, Baricitinib, a Janus kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis has been given emergency use authorization for the treatment of severe COVID-19 requiring oxygen supplementation.

Baricitinib is authorized for the treatment of COVID-19 in hospitalized adults and pediatric patients two years of age or older requiring supplemental oxygen, non-invasive or invasive mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.

Baricitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis. 

Oral Janus kinase inhibitors for rheumatoid arthritis are

  • Baricitinib 
  • Tofacitinib (Option A)

The 2 mg daily dose of baricitinib is currently FDA-approved for the treatment of adult patients with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis who have had an inadequate response to one or more tumor necrosis factor (TNF) antagonist therapies

Baricitinib showed a reduction in the proportion of patients who died through 28 days of follow-up compared to patients treated with the standard of care for COVID-19 alone. Baricitinib 4 mg once daily (orally) for 14 days or until hospital discharge was the regimen used.

Possible side effects of baricitinib :

  • Serious venous thrombosis, including pulmonary embolism
  • Serious infections have been observed in COVID-19 patients
  • It is not recommended for patients with
    • active tuberculosis infections
    • who are on dialysis
    • have end-stage renal disease
    • have acute kidney injury

Other options :

Leflunomide is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to methotrexate in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

Apremilast is a phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitor.

questions.text: As the chief medical officer of the Primary Health Centre (PHC), you are tasked with setting up a Near to Home COVID Vaccination Centre (NHCVC). Which of the following groups fall under the eligible population for vaccination at the NHCVC, as defined by the ministry of health and family welfare?

choices.text: Pregnant women in the third trimester
Individuals with comorbidities above the age of 45
Children under the age of 5 years

questions.solution:
Near to Home COVID Vaccination Centre is set up aimed at vaccinating individuals above 60 years of age and individuals below 60 years with disabilities due to physical or medical conditions.

Eligible population for COVID-19 vaccination at NHCVC is defined as:

  • All individuals above 60 years age with no vaccination or first dose vaccination
  • All individuals below 60 years with disability due to physical or medical conditions

The elderly usually have a high incidence of co-morbid conditions, making them more vulnerable to morbidity and mortality due to COVID-19 infection and its complications. Near to Home COVID Vaccination Centres are set up to vaccinate the most vulnerable population (elderly & the differently-abled) who may be left behind because of inability to travel to COVID-19 Vaccination Centers (CVC). It follows a community-based approach where sessions can be conducted in non-health facility-based settings and are nearer to home, e.g. in a community centre, RWA centre/office, panchayat ghar, school buildings, old age homes etc. These NHCVC will be organized specially for this target population only while vaccination for all other age groups will continue at the existing CVCs

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was rescued from a neglected household. The girl was in severe malnutrition and was therefore fed high-calorie meals at the rehabilitation home. She developed confusion and seizures. Investigations revealed that her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels were low. These electrolyte abnormalities are due to excessive administration of ____.
questions.solution:
The child in this case is suffering from refeeding syndrome, and her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels are low due to the increased serum insulin levels, which in turn is caused due to the excessive administration of carbohydrates.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting refeeding.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following:

  • Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Hypophosphatemia can produce the following manifestations:

  • Cardiac: Hypotension, Decreased stroke volume
  • Respiratory: Impaired diaphragm contractility, Dyspnea, Respiratory failure
  • Neurologic: Paresthesia, Weakness, Confusion, Disorientation, Lethargy, Areflexic paralysis, Seizures, Coma
  • Hematologic: Leukocyte dysfunction, Hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia

A controlled transition over 3 days is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: A  veterinarian presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen on his arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin in a veterinarian is strongly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis where the toxin acts by the increase in cAMP.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Bacillus anthracis may cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops which further develops into a vesicle. It later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a 'malignant pustule'. A majority of the patients tend to recover spontaneously. However, some patients may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease): It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Gastrointestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

  • Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.
  • Toxins that are made of three proteins-
    • Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell.
    • Edema factor (EF)- Is an adenylate cyclase, which is activated only inside the target cells, leading to intracellular accumulation of cyclic AMP and causing tissue edema.
    • Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Other options : 

Option A: Diptheria toxin and Pseudomonas acts by inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2).

Option C: Shiga toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inhibition of 60S ribosomal subunit.

Option D: Some strains of Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) produce a heat-stable toxin that acts by an increase in cGMP.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in a drowsy state with difficulty in breathing. The consultant suspects transection of the brainstem at the level indicated in the image given below, with intact vagal innervation. What will be the type of respiration expected in this patient?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but with deep inspiration

questions.solution:
Transection of the brain stem midway between the pons and the medulla with intact vagal innervation causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

The pre-Botzinger complex in the medulla consists of synaptically coupled pacemaker cells. These neurons help in initiating the process of respiration. They also help in producing rhythmic and automatic respiration.

The pneumotaxic center in the pons modifies this rhythmic discharge and regularizes it. This center mainly controls the rate and depth of breathing. The apneustic center excites the inspiratory center and causes prolongation of the action potential. This helps in maintaining the period of respiration. 

So a complete transection midway between the pons and medulla causes irregular respiration. 

Respiratory centers of the brain:

  • Pre-Botzinger complex - This produces rhythmic and automatic respiration. Therefore damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration.
  • Pneumotaxic center - The rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botziger complex is further modified by the pneumotaxic centers. Stimulation of the pneumotaxic center results in an increase in the respiratory rate and a decrease in the tidal volume. There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis).
  • Vagus nerve - Stretching of the lung initiates impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore in vagotomy, there is an increased depth of inspiration. 
  • Therefore, damage to pons causes respiration to become slower and tidal volume to become greater.  

 

Other options:

Option A- Apneusis occurs in transection through the mid-pontine level with a vagotomy.

Option B- Spontaneous respiration ceases in a complete transection through the medulla.

Option C- Regular breathing with deep inspiration occurs in complete transection above the pons.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and tenesmus. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple, continuous lesions in the rectum and rectosigmoid without normal mucosa in between. The mucosa was red and the surface was fine granular like sandpaper. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is a mucosal disease that primarily involves rectum and extends proximally to involves some parts or whole of the colon. It can cause proctitis, proctocolitis, and colitis.

The involvement of the mucosa in UC is continuous without any normal mucosa in between. The various mucosal changes in different stages of UC are as follows: 

  • Mild disease - mucosa appears erythematous with fine granular surface resembling sandpaper
  • Severe disease - mucosa is hemorrhagic, edematous, and ulcerated
  • Long-standing disease - inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) due to epithelial regeneration.

Microscopically UC shows the following findings: 

  • Inflammation that is limited to mucosa and submucosa
  • Distortion of the crypt architecture with the following changes - 
    • Bifid and reduced number of crypts
    • Gap between the crypt base and muscularis mucosae is seen
    • Cryptitis and crypt abscesses - due to crypt invasion by neutrophils
  • Basal plasma cells and multiple basal lymphoid aggregates
  • Mucosal vascular congestion with edema and focal haemorrhage 
  • Mucosal inflammatory cell infiltration by neutrophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages 
  • Backwash ileitis with:
    • Villous atrophy and crypt regeneration
    • Increased neutrophil and mononuclear inflammation in the lamina propria
    • Patchy cryptitis and crypt abscesses

The below image shows pseudopolyps in ulcerative colitis.

The below image shows the histology of ulcerative colitis.

Clinical features of UC include: Crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, passing of mucus in stools and tenesmus. 

Other options: 

Option A: Crohn's disease (CD) manifests as ileocolitis with right lower quadrant pain, palpable mass, fever, leukocytosis and weight loss. Other features like elevated ESR and CRP are seen. Endoscopy shows rectal sparing, fistulas, skip lesions and transmural inflammation. 

Option B: Diverticulitis is a close differential for Crohn's disease and is characterised by features such as fever, abdominal pain, mass, elevated ESR and leukocytosis. Endoscopic features are less appreciable in this condition than in CD.

Option C: Ischaemic colitis is typically characterised by sudden onset of left lower quadrant pain and bleeding per rectum following repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm or in a patient with cardiac/peripheral vascular disease.

questions.text: Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of myeloid leukemia.

    • X-rays

    • β particles

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Wood's lamp examination shows pale yellow fluorescence. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk and lesions showing a pale yellow fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination are pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. versicolor: azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species. The site most commonly affected is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen (seborrheic areas). The term versicolor refers to the different colors of the scales from a pale ochre to medium brown.

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign. Relapse is very common. 

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration.

The image below shows hypopigmented macules and patches of Pityriasis versicolor-

 

Other options-

Option (A): Segmental vitiligo- Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is an acquired condition resulting from the progressive loss of melanocytes. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules which occur unilaterally in segmental type. (image given below). Wood's lamp examination shows ivory or milky white fluorescence. The presence of a family history of vitiligo, the Koebner phenomenon, leukotrichia, or associated autoimmune disorders such as thyroid disease can help to support a clinical diagnosis of vitiligo.

 

Option (C): Tinea corporis is a ringworm of the glabrous skin. It is caused by dermatophytes - Trichophyton rubrum, Epidermophyton floccosum, Microspora, etc. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. Scaling and central resolution are also common. (image below)

 

Option (D): Nevus anemicus is a congenital vascular anomaly that presents clinically as a hypopigmented macule or patch. The lesional pallor is due to a localized hypersensitivity to catecholamines with resultant vasoconstriction. Hence, the pallor completely disappears under Wood’s light and the diascopy of adjacent skin reveals an identical color to that of the ‘depigmented’ area. Clinically, nevus anemicus is a circumscribed, rounded, oval, or linear pale macule or patch with irregular margins that may be surrounded by satellite macules. (image given below). Lesions typically are asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A hypertensive male patient presents to you with complaints of tingling sensations over his legs. Investigations revealed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody screening, and fibrinoid necrosis on skin tissue biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is polyarteritis nodosa. 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries, especially renal and visceral arteries. Affected individuals usually present with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and weight loss. Other symptoms include arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, abdominal pain, and rashes. Involvement of the renal arteries can manifest as renal failure or hypertension. 

In chronic cases, a biopsy of affected sites such as skin lesions shows fibrinoid necrosis of the vessels under microscopy as shown below. Aneurysmal dilatations up to 1 centimeter of the involved arteries is characteristic.

 

Investigations will show raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and leukocytosis. Patients are generally managed with a combination of prednisone and cyclophosphamide. The prognosis in untreated cases is poor.

Other options:

Option B: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the respiratory tract along with glomerulonephritis. Symptoms include bloody nasal discharge, hemoptysis, cough, and hematuria. In advanced cases, renal failure can occur. Airway biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with necrosis. Laboratory findings include positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), raised ESR, and leukocytosis. 

The image below shows a lung biopsy observed under the microscope:

 

Option C: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), is marked by eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis. It is an ANCA-positive small vessel vasculitis and presents with asthmatic attacks, fever, and weight loss. ESR and CRP are usually elevated. Biopsy shows granulomas with eosinophilic infiltration of tissues as shown below:

 

Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (IgA vasculitis), is a type of small vessel vasculitis commonly seen in children. It is usually preceded by streptococcal pharyngitis. They present with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and hematuria. Mild leukocytosis and raised IgA levels might be seen. A skin biopsy will show immunoglobulin A (IgA) deposition under direct immunofluorescence as shown below:

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with hepatitis C infection now presents to the hospital with reddish-colored urine. Urine analysis was performed, and it shows proteinuria and the presence of red blood cells and leucocytes in the urine. A renal biopsy was performed, and the obtained sample was stained with periodic acid-Schiff (image A) and methenamine silver (image B). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is diagnosed with hepatitis C, presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and pyuria and histological examination shows the thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, giving rise to the tram-track appearance. The most likely diagnosis in this case is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is immune-mediated glomerulonephritis characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with mesangio-proliferative changes.

Types:

Type I MPGN is commonly associated with persistent hepatitis C infections, autoimmune diseases like SLE or cryoglobulinemia, or neoplastic diseases of the lung, breast, and ovary. 

Type II and type III are mediated by the complement pathways.

Histopathology:

On light microscopy, type I MPGN will show the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. At some points, the GBM splits showing the tram track appearance. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits.

Type II MPGN can also have GBM thickening and splitting. The glomerular tuft has a lobular appearance. On electron microscopy, it shows dense deposits. Subendothelial deposits are generally absent.

Type III MPGN is rare and shows focal mesangial proliferation. The image below shows the thickening and splitting of GBM.

Other options

Option A- Crescentic glomerulonephritis is seen in patients developing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In this, the serum creatinine levels increase very rapidly. Microscopy will show the presence of crescents within the glomeruli.

Option C - Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is usually a primary disease, but rarely can be associated with diseases like Hodgkin’s lymphoma, allergies, or the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents. Light microscopy appears normal. Electron microscopy may show the effacement of foot processes.

Option D - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis manifests as proteinuria. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It can be a primary disease or occur as a result of HIV, hepatitis B, hypertension, Alport syndrome, etc. The biopsy will show the focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with recurrent bouts of vomiting and abdominal cramps over the past three hours. He gives a history of consumption of fried rice at a restaurant 5 hours back. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette showing food poisoning within 2 hours of consumption of fried rice/ Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (serotypes 1, 3, 5) food poisoning.

Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus: one involves the stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other is independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8–16 hours 1–5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

B. cereus produces lecithinase and ferments glucose but not mannitol. The presence of 1,00,000 or more bacteria per gram of stool is diagnostic. Anything less than that may be present as normal flora in the gut. Both types of illnesses are mild and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Food poisoning by Clostridium perfringens is usually caused by the consumption of cold or warmed-up meat dishes. After an incubation period of 8-24 hours, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting set in. Isolating heat-resistant C. perfringens type A from feces and food is used for the diagnosis.

Option B: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours. Demonstration of the enterotoxins is helpful to establish the diagnosis. It causes traveler's diarrhea in people from non-endemic areas visiting endemic areas.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning. It presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after 2–6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Meat, fish, milk, and milk products that are cooked and left at room temperature after contamination with Staphylococci, for a long enough time for the toxin to accumulate, are usually responsible. The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with crampy abdominal pain, constipation, and bloating on and off for the past 10 years. Pain occurs frequently after meals and is relieved after defecation without any bleeding while defecating. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's condition is irritable bowel syndrome with constipation and the drug used for this condition is lubiprostone.

The ROME IV criteria is used to diagnose irritable bowel syndrome, which requires at least 3 days a month in the last 3 months associated with 2 or more of the following:

  • improvement in abdominal pain or discomfort with defecation
  • onset associated with a change in frequency of stool
  • and/or an onset accompanied by a change in form or appearance of stool

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating the Cl-channels opening in the intestine and increasing liquid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Other options:

Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist which is indicated only for women with severe diarrhea-predominant IBS who have chronic IBS symptoms ( lasting 6 months or longer) and have not responded adequately to conventional therapy. Serious GI adverse reactions like ischemic colitis, serious complications of constipation have been associated with its usage.

Rifaximin is indicated for irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea (IBS-D) in adult men and women.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Meniere’s disease presented with a history of sudden fall without loss of consciousness and no associated neurological or cardiovascular symptoms. On examination, there were no neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Its pathogenesis is not well understood.

Tullio phenomenon: It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Lermoyez syndrome: Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is being evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. She traveled to Brazil on a business trip 5 months ago. Barium swallow reveals the following finding. Which of the following could have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infection with Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected.

The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophageal dilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas' disease.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the glycolytic pathway. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate after adding alanine, which is a non-competitive inhibitor. Which of the following graphs shows the effect caused by alanine?

choices.text: The type of plot will depend on the relative concentration of alanine and enzyme.

questions.solution:
Graph C represents non-competitive inhibition. The inhibition of pyruvate kinase by alanine is an example of non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Lineweaver-Burk plot is also known as the double reciprocal plot.

Competitive inhibition (graph A) - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Uncompetitive inhibition (graph B) - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased. Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan isoenzyme) by phenylalanine is an example of uncompetitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was found to have the following  arterial blood gas (ABG ) test findings. The pH is 7.24, serum bicarbonate is 18mEq/L, pCO2 is 35mmHg. Which of the following is the most common cause of the given ABG presentation in children?
questions.solution:
The given ABG findings is suggestive of metabolic acidosis because the pH is low (acidosis) with low bicarbonate (metabolic) and normal pCO2 levels. Diarrhea is the most common cause of metabolic acidosis in children overall, because of the loss of bicarbonates from the body.

Acidosis can be due to either low serum bicarbonate/increased organic acids (metabolic) or high pCO2 (respiratory). The normal values in ABG are:

  • pH = 7.35-7.45
  • [HCO3] = 22-28 mEq/L
  • pCO2 = 35-45 mmHg
  • Anion gap = 4-11

The amount of bicarbonate lost in the stool depends on the volume of diarrhea and the bicarbonate concentration of the stool, which tends to increase with more severe diarrhea.

Causes of Metabolic acidosis include,

Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

  • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

  • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)
  • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)
  • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient presents with the following lesion on his right leg which has been present for the last 7 days. He is on medication for hypertension and diabetes for the past 10 years.  He is a known epileptic on treatment and also frequently takes painkillers for osteoarthritis of both knees. The patient gives a history of similar lesions on the same site over the past few years which resolve spontaneously after 7-10 days. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug. The drugs causing fixed drug eruptions are:

  • Sulphonamides
  • NSAIDs
  • Analgesics
  • Hypnotics 

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Other options: Sodium Valproate, Captopril, Metformin do not cause Fixed drug eruptions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient was evaluated for recurrent pregnancy loss. Her hysterosalpingogram and sonography revealed a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to this condition?

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of eggs in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an oval egg with rhabditiform larvae indicate infection by Strongyloides stercoralis.

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

 Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Thin-walled
  • Transparent
  • Ovoid in shape
  • Contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

It is unique among human nematodes as it has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil. The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of Strongyloides is the filariform larva. When a person walks barefoot on soil containing the infective filariform larvae, they penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

Here, the larvae molt twice and become adult female worms. The eggs laid by the female in the intestinal mucosa hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

This autoinfection is not seen in Ancylostoma or Necator life cycle.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: You are promoted to the position of district medical officer. While getting oriented, you learn that your district recorded an Annual parasite index (API) of 1.7 in the year 2015. Which category does your district fall under according to the National Strategic Plan for Malaria (2017-2022)?
questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the districts under Category 2 of the NVBDCP as districts/units having API one and above but less than two per 1000 population. These districts are said to be under the pre-elimination phase.

The goal of the National Strategic Plan for Malaria for Category 2 districts is to completely eliminate malaria by the year 2022.

Category Definition API
Category 0 Prevention of re-establishment phase No incidence in last 3 years
Category 1 Elimination phase < 1 per 1000 population
Category 2 Pre elimination phase 1-2 per 1000 population
Category 3 Intensified control phase > 2 per 1000 population

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient experiences aspiration but does not exhibit any change in voice following base of skull surgery. This suggests an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN). 

In SLN injury, only the cricothyroid muscle is involved which is used only in high-pitch vocalization, normal speech will not be affected. SLN also provides sensory supply to the mucosa above vocal cords, hence its lesion would lead to increased susceptibility to aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: The glossopharyngeal nerve does not provide sensory or motor supply to the larynx. 

Option C and D: The patient also has normal vocalization which rules out recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and high vagal injury. RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid, therefore an RLN lesion would lead to disordered vocalization. A high vagal injury would mean that both the SLN and RLN functions are affected, therefore that can also be ruled out.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction.

choices.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium
Thiazides increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium
Thiazides cause water loss therby increase lithium levels

questions.solution:
Thiazides act by increasing the tubular reabsorption of lithium.

Thiazide use is accompanied by sodium loss which is compensated in a few days by increased reabsorption of Na+ in the proximal tubule.

The kidney handles both lithium and Na+ in the same way. Thus, along with Na+ reabsorption, there will be an increase in the reabsorption of lithium also, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A  hosteller developed papules with excoriation in the interdigital web spaces, groin, and under-surface of the breasts. She tells that lesions are intensely pruritic at night and her roommate has similar complaints. Identify the wrong statement about the vector causing this condition, shown in the image below.

choices.text: Life cycle of  the vector has 4 stages
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive of scabies. The given image depicts an itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The incorrect statement is that the male parasite burrows into the epidermis.

The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow. A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow. The larval stage, which emerges from the eggs, has 3 pairs of legs. After the larvae moult, the resulting nymphs have 4 pairs of legs.

The life cycle has 4 stages- egg, larva, nymph, and adult. It takes about 10-15 days to progress from egg to adult. However, the adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasites in the epidermis. Clinical features include itching severe at night, superficial burrows in the affected site, and secondary infection of the lesions leading to crusted papules and pustules. Multiple members of a household may be affected, hence simultaneous treatment of all the household contacts is essential.

 

The diagnosis is made by visualizing the parasite in skin debris under a microscope. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 40-year old male patient was referred to you with the features of testicular and renal tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you identified the presence of parathyroid and pituitary adenoma and hence advised him to undergo chromosomal studies. The gene mutation responsible for this condition is located on ___________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of MEN 4 syndrome which is caused by germline mutations in the CDKN1B gene, located on chromosome 12.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is characterized by the occurrence of tumors involving two or more endocrine glands within a single patient.

MEN 4 comprises:

  • Reproductive organ tumors such as testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical cancer
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Note :

  • MEN 1 is caused by a germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin protein),  tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 11.
  • MEN 2(both 2A and 2B) is caused by a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, located on chromosome 10.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:

    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
