questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of fever and painful burning lesions on his right knee as shown in the image below. The patient is concerned that he may spread the disease to his family. What is your advice regarding the period of isolation?

choices.text: During full course of the disease

questions.solution: A systemic response (fever), along with prodromal symptoms like pain and presence of grouped herpetiform vesicles developing on the erythematous base is classical of Herpes zoster infection. The recommended period of isolation is 6 days after the onset of rash.

questions.text: As a pathologist, you receive a brain biopsy of the frontal cortex of a 66-year-old male, which shows the following on silver staining. The patient's case sheet shows memory impairment as the chief complaint. Which of the following conditions is this patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological sample from the frontal cortex showing show a characteristic swelling containing cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous Pick bodies are inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods which are found in Pick's disease which falls under the Frontotemporal dementias.

Pick's disease is a form of Frontotemporal lobar degenerations (FTLDs) - tau where the affected cortical regions demonstrate progressive neuronal loss and reactive gliosis, along with the presence of cytoplasmic tau inclusions in neurons. Smooth contoured inclusions (Pick bodies) are seen in Pick's disease.

Like most neurodegenerative diseases, FTLD is associated with cellular inclusions comprised of specific proteins; the two most common patterns are those with tau inclusions (FTLD-tau) and those with TDP-43 inclusions (FTLD-TDP)

Dementia is defined as a disease process marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Depending on the site of the cerebral lesions, the dementias are classified as cortical or subcortical.

Subcortical dementias are associated with movement disorders, gait apraxia, psychomotor retardation, apathy, and akinetic mutism. They include:

  • Huntington's disease
  • Parkinson's disease
  • Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Vascular dementia
  • Wilson's disease

Cortical dementias are associated with aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia. They include:

  • Alzheimer's type of dementia
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)
  • Pick's disease

Other options :

Dementia of Lewy Bodies : It is characterised by the presence of Lewy bodies, which is an eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion that contains both neurofilaments and alpha-synuclein. In addition to dementia, a patient with probable DLB must have at least two "core clinical features" of DLB: cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD), and parkinsonism.

Alzheimer's disease : Alzheimer disease is a β-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein and tau deposition while FTLD-tau shows only tau aggregation and accumulation. Pick's disease is characteristic in that, the inclusions are smooth and contoured while other FTLD-tau show tangles which resemble the ones seen in Alzheimer's disease.

Vascular dementia : Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging is noticed in vascular dementia.

questions.text: A 51-year-old post COVID patient developed nasal discharge, painful swelling, redness over the right cheek and blurry vision of the right eye followed by a headache. A sinus biopsy specimen showed the following appearance on histology. Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the given organism?

choices.text: They are classified under the phylum Glomerulomycota.
Culture is done on sabouraud agar, along with antibacterial agents and cycloheximide.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is strongly suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. The fungi can be isolated on Sabouraud agar, along with antibacterial agents, but without cycloheximide.

Biopsy confirms this diagnosis by revealing non-septate hyphae branching at right-angles, which are characteristic of Mucorales such as Rhizopus delemar. The hyphae are broad (10–15 μm) with uneven thickness, irregular branching, and sparse septations.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by a number of molds classified in the order ‘Mucorales’ of the phylum ‘Glomerulomycota’ and subphylum ‘Mucormycotina’. 

These fungi are ubiquitous thermotolerant saprobes. The leading pathogens among this group are species of the genera Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Their spores are present in air and dust. They are often seen to contaminate stale bread. 

Angio-invasiveness is one of the characteristics of zygomycosis which makes it fatal in invasive infections- the orbit, sinuses and the brain; the lung may also be the primary site of infection. Almost all patients are immunocompromised.

When the lung is the primary site of infection, the fungi may invade the arteries to cause thrombosis and infarction.

Diagnosis:

Specimen:

  • Exudate: wet preparation is made in 10% potassium hydroxide. Broad, ribbon-like hyphae are seen.
  • Tissue: Hematoxylin & eosin stain shows none-septate, broad hyphae, often invading into blood vessels.

Culture:

Isolation is by culture on Sabouraud agar with antibacterial agent but without cycloheximide. After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37 degree Celsius, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cotton, fluffy surface.

Clinical suspicion based on the given symptoms in a diabetic/immunosuppressed individual should prompt immediate treatment with liposomal amphotericin B.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
You are a part of a research team working on a new rapid diagnostic screening test for COVID. The following table shows the results of 10,000 people who took the new screening test. Calculate the positive predictive value of this screening test.
  Disease - Present Disease - Absent
Screening test - Positive 40 20
Screening test - Negative 100 9840
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value of this screening test is 66.6%. Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease. 

This is calculated using the following formula :

(TP/TP+FP) x 100

where,

TP - True positive (Screening test and diagnosis is positive for the disease)

FP - False positive (Screening test is positive but the diagnosis is negative)

In this scenario :

(40/40+20) x 100 = (40/60) x 100 = 0.666 x 100 = 66.6%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

FP + TN

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct statements regarding the basal electrical rhythm of the GI tract?
  1. The membrane potential is between -100 and -70mV.
  2. They are initiated by the Interstitial cells of Cajal.
  3. In the stomach, these cells are located in the oblique layer.
  4. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to sodium influx.
  5. Epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and tension.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 5 are correct. Basal Electrical Rhythm is produced by interstitial cells of Cajal and epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and tension.

The Basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV. (Statement 1)

Sites and rhythm:

The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach. In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. (Statement 3)

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

Spike potentials on BER:

  • The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension.
  • The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to calcium influx (Statement 4) and the repolarizing portion is due to potassium efflux.
  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

Role of BER:

  • Muscle contraction can occur only when the motor stimulus is provided during the depolarisation part of the BER.
  • Thus, BER does not cause muscle contraction by itself, but controls the rate and organization sites of the muscle contractions, as in coordination of the peristaltic activity and setting the rhythm of segmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome?

choices.text: Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the patients
Doppler ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice
It becomes clinically significant when one or more major hepatic veins are obstructed
Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor

questions.solution:
Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow and it becomes clinically significant when two or more major hepatic veins are obstructed.

Types: 

  • Primary  Budd–Chiari syndrome: when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venous thrombosis.
  • Secondary Budd–Chiari syndrome:  when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighboring lesion originating outside the vein.

Most common presentation: ascites and abdominal discomfort.

Risk factors include-Primary myeloproliferative disorders, anticardiolipin antibodies, hyperhomocysteinemia, and oral contraceptive use.

Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the cases and it is because the caudate lobe drains directly into the IVC.

Abdominal ultrasonography with color Doppler is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins.

The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as measure inferior vena cava (IVC) pressures.

questions.text: Acute onset inattention with disorganized thinking and altered level of consciousness is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Acute onset inattention with disorganized thinking and altered level of consciousness is characteristic of delirium.

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a diagnostic algorithm for delirium. The diagnosis of delirium requires the presence of features 1 and 2 and either feature 3 or 4.

  • Feature 1: Acute onset and fluctuating course
    • Positive responses to the following questions satisfy this feature:
      Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient’s baseline? Does it fluctuate during the day, or does it increase and decrease in severity?
  • Feature 2: Inattention
    • Positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Is there difficulty focusing attention, easily distractibility, or difficulty keeping track of what was being said?
  • Feature 3: Disorganized thinking
    • A positive response to the following question satisfies this feature: Was the patient’s thinking disorganized or incoherent. Was there rambling or irrelevant conversation, an unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject?
  • Feature 4: Altered level of consciousness
    • This feature is satisfied by any answer other than “alert” to the following question: Rate the patient’s level of consciousness: alert (normal), vigilant (hyperalert), lethargic (drowsy, easily aroused), stupor (difficult to arouse), or coma (unarousable)?

The scale may not identify the full spectrum of patients with delirium, but all patients who are acutely confused should be presumed delirious. A course that fluctuates over hours or days and may worsen at night is known as sundowning. It is typically seen in delirium, but is not essential for the diagnosis.

Other screening tools that can aid in identifying patients with delirium are:

  • Nursing Delirium Screening Scale (NuDESC)
  • Organic Brain Syndrome Scale
  • Delirium Rating Scale
  • ICU version of the CAM
  • Delirium Detection Score

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was undergoing a transurethral resection of the prostate. His blood pressure before anaesthesia is 120/75 mmHg and his pulse rate is 78/min. Few minutes after the spinal anaesthesia, the patient complained of nausea, vomiting, and dizziness and his blood pressure dropped to 85/56 mmHg and pulse rate to 65/min. All of the following are risk factors for this condition except?

choices.text: Age older than or equal to 40 years.
Peak block height greater than or equal to T5.
Spinal puncture at or above the L3-L4 interspace.

questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, the patient is diagnosed to have spinal anaesthesia induced hypotension. Spinal puncture at or above the L2-L3 interspace is a risk factor for its development, not L3-L4 interspace. 

Risk factors for spinal-anesthesia-induced hypotension:

  • Peak block height greater than or equal to T5
  • Age older than or equal to 40 years
  • Baseline systolic blood pressure less than 120 mm Hg
  • Combined spinal and general anesthesia
  • Spinal puncture at or above the L2-L3 interspace

Clinical features:

  • SBP < 90 mmHg
  • Nausea precedes hypotension (first symptom to appear)
  • Apnea due to medullary hypoperfusion
  • Bradycardia

 Treatment:

  • Rapid administration of intravenous fluids
  • Head-down position (only after local anesthesia is fixed (~20 minutes for bupivacaine), else, hyperbaric solution can ascend and lead to high spinal)
  • Intravenous vasopressors (ephedrine, phenylephrine)
  • Bradycardia is treated with atropine

NOTE:

Spinal-anesthesia-induced hypotension is treated with ephedrine (most commonly), mephentermine or phenylephrine. Epinephrine is reserved only for refractory hypotension or cardiac arrest following spinal anesthesia.

Related Pearl: Complications of neuraxial (spinal and epidural) anesthesia

  • Transient neurological symptoms (Lidocaine, chloroprocaine with preservative)

questions.text: A primi mother in her 6th week of gestation comes to the PHC for an antenatal check-up. Incidentally, she tests positive for COVID in the screening camp held in the PHC but she is asymptomatic. She enquires about getting vaccinated against COVID -19 to you, the Medical Officer of the PHC . When would you advise her to get vaccinated?

choices.text: After recovery from COVID during the first trimester
4 weeks after recovery from COVID during pregnancy
8 weeks after recovery from COVID during pregnancy

questions.solution:
A woman who has been infected with COVID-19 infection during the current pregnancy should be vaccinated soon after the delivery.

Global recommendations of covid vaccination in pregnant women : 

  • WHO recommends the use of recombinant vaccine in pregnant women, provided the benefits of vaccination outweigh the potential risk. Pregnant women may also be exposed to the COVID-19 vaccine before the woman knows she is pregnant.
  • WHO does not recommend pregnancy testing prior to vaccination and delaying pregnancy or terminating a pregnancy because of vaccination
  • International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) believes that a risk-based approach to immunization might be of disadvantage to the pregnant woman
  • The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (RCOG) states that pregnant women should be offered the vaccine as the general population
  • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) states that pregnancy testing should not be required prior to receiving a vaccine and the vaccine may be administered to the people who may consider future pregnancy. Women under age 50 including pregnant women can receive any COVID-19 vaccine. However, they should be aware of the rare risk of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome after receipt of mRNA vaccines

COVID-19 vaccines available are safe and vaccination protects pregnant women against COVID 19 illness/disease like other individuals. Like any medicine, a vaccine may have side effects which are normally mild. After getting the vaccine injection, she can get a mild fever, pain at the injection site, or feel unwell for 1-3 days. The long-term adverse effects and safety of the vaccine for fetus and child is not established yet

Note : The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has approved the vaccination of pregnant women against COVID. However, in the case of a woman testing positive for COVID-19 during the current pregnancy, current guidelines state that the woman should be vaccinated soon after delivery, regardless of the weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A patient with crocodile tears syndrome has spontaneous lacrimation during eating. The lesion is located at:

choices.text: Facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
In a patient with crocodile tears syndrome, the lesion is located proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

Crocodile tears syndrome or Bogorad syndrome (Gustatory lacrimation): 

  • The patient has spontaneous lacrimation with response to the stimuli such as smell or taste of food.
  • It is seen in the cases where the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During the regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland. Hence the person has lacrimation during eating.

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady comes to the OPD with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and itching over her arms and legs. On examination, there is presence of icterus and mild hepatomegaly. Liver function test shows deranged values. A liver biopsy shows the following findings. The patient also tests positive for anti-nuclear antibodies and an elevated level of serum IgG. Which of the following features is not present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with a positive ANA test and increased serum IgG levels with histopathology showing interface hepatitis, a cluster of plasma cells and lymphocytes at the interface between the portal tract and liver lobule, indicates Autoimmune hepatitis(AIH). All the features are found in AIH except “ground glass” hepatocytes which are characteristically found in Hepatitis B and is a diagnostic hallmark.

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

  • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
  • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Based on the types of autoantibodies present, autoimmune hepatitis is subclassified as types 1 and 2 :

  • Type 1 disease (more common overall) -
    • Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) 
    • Anti–smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies
    • Antibodies against soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas antigen (SLA/LPA)
    • Less commonly, anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA, more typical of primary biliary cholangitis) also may be seen. 
  • Type 2 disease (more common in children) - 
    • Anti liver-kidney-microsome-1 (LKM-1) antibodies, which are directed against CYP2D6
    • Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies.

The simplified scoring system for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis includes four variables. They are:

  1. Autoantibodies
  2. Elevated serum IgG level
  3. Typical compatible histologic features
  4. Absence of viral hepatitis markers

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: The national family planning program has implemented new contraception methods and incentives. You are asked to assess the effect of the new strategy. Which of the following indicators will you use?
questions.solution:
The indicator used to assess the effect of the new strategy will be the total fertility rate (TFR).

TFR is denoted by the average number of children that would be born to a lady if she had the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive years (15-49 years), during a specific year. It is the summation of all age-specific fertility rates(ASFR). TFR represents the approximate magnitude of the completed family size. The total number of children that a woman delivers during her childbearing age is called the completed family size. 

The formula is TFR = (45-49∑15-19 ASFR) x 5/1000.

ASFR is represented by the number of live births in a year to 1000 women in any specified age group. The formula is:

ASFR = (Number of live births in a particular age group/Mid-year female population of the same age group) x 1000

Other options:

Option C: Gross reproductive rate (GRR) represents the average number of girls that would be delivered by a woman if she continues to have the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span with no infant mortality. The formula is:

GRR = (45-49∑15-19 ASFR for female live births)x 5/1000

Option D: General fertility rate (GFR) is defined as the number of live births per 1000 women aged between 15-44 or 49 years i.e. in their reproductive time period in a given year. The formula is: 

GFR = (Number of live births in an area during the year/Mid-year female population age 15- 44 (or 49) in the same area in the same year) x 1000

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text:
You are a part of a research group spearheading human trials on patients affect by Sars-CoV-2 which are variants of interest. Patients infected with which of the following variants would be chosen for this trial?
  1. Iota
  2. Delta
  3. Kappa
  4. Gamma
  5. Alpha
  6. Lambda
questions.solution:
Patients infected with the Iota, Lambda, and Kappa variants would be chosen for this trial.

A Variant Classification scheme that defines three classes of SARS-CoV-2 variants:

  • Variant of Interest
  • Variant of Concern
  • Variant of High Consequence

Variants of Interest (VOI)

The working definition of VOI is a SARS-CoV-2 variant :

  • with genetic changes that are predicted or known to affect virus characteristics such as transmissibility, disease severity, immune escape, diagnostic or therapeutic escape; AND
  • Identified to cause significant community transmission or multiple COVID-19 clusters, in multiple countries with increasing relative prevalence alongside an increasing number of cases over time, or other apparent epidemiological impacts to suggest an emerging risk to global public health.

Variants under the VOI :

  • Eta 
  • Iota 
  • Kappa 
  • Lambda

Variants of Concern (VOC)

The working definition:

A SARS-CoV-2 variant that meets the definition of a VOI and, through a comparative assessment, has been demonstrated to be associated with one or more of the following changes at a degree of global public health significance:

  • Increase in transmissibility or detrimental change in COVID-19 epidemiology; OR
  • Increase in virulence or change in clinical disease presentation; OR
  • Decrease in effectiveness of public health and social measures or available diagnostics, vaccines, therapeutics.

Variants classified as VOC :

  • Alpha 
  • Beta 
  • Gamma 
  • Delta
  • Omicron

 

NOTE:

WHO has recently classified a new variant, B.1.1.529, as a variant of concern and has named it Omicron. It was first identified in South Africa. There are various amino acid substitutions, deletions, and small insertions in the spike protein of this variant. This indicates that the Omicron variant might be more transmissible than the original SARS-CoV-2 virus.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. He recently also developed severe pain in his right knee. A malabsorption syndrome is suspected and a biopsy is taken which shows the following picture. A disturbance in which phase of nutrient absorption is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing foul-smelling diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and histopathology showing dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria and macrophages containing periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules is suggestive of Whipple disease where there is a disturbance in the lymphatic transport of absorbed lipids.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and central nervous system & cardiac problems. The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive fecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-colored stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn's disease. In Whipple disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

  • Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.
  • Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with P2L2 presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and the adnexa is free. On further investigation, the uterus shows the following finding seen on the MRI. The patient doesn't desire any more children. What will be the initial plan of management for this patient?

IUD- Intrauterine device
questions.solution:
The clinical history of menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic discomfort in a parous woman and a symmetrically enlarged uterus on examination are suggestive of adenomyosis.  Sagittal MRI of this woman's pelvis shows a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. The initial step in management is diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

Etiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous women >40 years
  • Most common symptom - Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Per-Vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy
  • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign - Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical. The uterus is symmetrically enlarged and rarely exceeds 14 weeks in size.
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • TVS or MRI ( MRI is superior to USG in showing hypo or anechoic areas in the uterine wall)

Management:

  • A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management of adenomyosis (because of menorrhagia).
  • Total Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD, Mirena is tried in younger women

IMAGE: The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of hemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis. Uterine size rarely exceeds 14 weeks in adenomyosis.

 

Note:

Uterine Artery Embolization/Uterine Fibroid Embolization (UAE/UFE) is a promising non-surgical alternative treatment option for patients with menorrhagia and adenomyosis. It is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. Because vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, sparing the surrounding myometrium. UAE helped in decreasing the uterine size and junctional zone thickness in cases of adenomyosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological picture showing the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape) and lymphocytes and clinical history is suggestive of tuberculosis.

Clinically, tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

Other options:

Option C- Sarcoidosis shows giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

Option D- Syphilis shows thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

questions.text:
A 5-week old infant was brought to the clinic with projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, there is a firm, ovoid abdominal mass which is 1-2 cm. An erect x-ray of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is a risk factor for this condition?
  1. Klinefelter syndrome
  2. Turner syndrome
  3. Down syndrome
  4. Edwards syndrome
  5. Patau syndrome
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) which is associated with Turner syndrome and trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

  • It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age
  • Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk. M: F= 5:1
  • Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting.
  • Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right (not from right to left), followed by projectile vomiting.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Trisomy 18
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis is a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman was shifted to the observation room after a surgery in which a certain topical anesthetic was used. An hour later, the patient was found to be cyanotic and diaphoretic, with a room air oxygen saturation of 89%. Despite the use of a non-rebreathing face mask, the patient remained hypoxic, with oxygen saturation of around 86%. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the cause of the patient's condition?

ABG shows:

pH- 7.35

pCO2- 37 mm Hg

HCO3- 24 mEq/L

pO2- 33.6 mm Hg
questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of methemoglobinemia, which is a common side effect of prilocaine.

The possible diagnosis of methemoglobinemia can be made because the patient is cyanosed, the cyanosis is unresponsive to ventilation, there is no prior history of respiratory problems, and the patient is exposed to a topical anesthetic during the procedure that is known to cause methemoglobinemia. The hepatic metabolism of prilocaine generates O-toluidine, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia risk is directly associated with the total dose administered, usually appearing when doses exceed 8 mg/kg.

Pulse oximetry is used as an important assessment of oxygenation. It uses plethysmography and light absorbance measurements at two wavelengths to estimate oxygen saturation. It is inaccurate when more than two types of hemoglobin are present. This is because abnormal hemoglobin (methemoglobin) is not picked up by pulse oximetry. Pulse oximetry data (SpO2) should therefore be used with caution in patients with methemoglobinemia. Pulse oximetry with low levels of methemoglobinemia shows low levels of O2 saturation, and at high levels of methemoglobinemia shows high levels of O2 saturation.

Methemoglobinemia causes cyanosis, which does not respond to oxygen administration. Methemoglobin level assay is the best way to diagnose this condition. Levels >15% cause cerebral ischemia, whilst 60% blood level may cause fatality. Oxygen saturation in pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia plateaus at 85%

Intravenous administration of methylene blue is the treatment for methemoglobinemia.

Benzocaine can also cause methemoglobinemia, similar to prilocaine. The risk of methemoglobinemia due to Procaine, Bupivacaine, and Ropivacaine is significantly lower as compared to Prilocaine and Benzocaine.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with a mild cough tested COVID-19 positive and was advised home quarantine. Which of the following statements is true regarding biomedical waste management in this scenario?

Water bottles and tetra packs used by him are considered biomedical waste
The masks used by him are to be collected in yellow bags
General waste bags are sprayed with 10% sodium hypochlorite solution prior to disposal

questions.solution:
The masks used by patients with COVID-19 are collected in yellow bags.

Waste from quarantine homes/camps or home-care facilities with COVID-19 patients are disposed of in the following manner:

  • The masks used by them are collected in yellow bags as well. They are placed in separate bins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Image 2 depicting crusts (scabs) are not a primary lesion.

Crusts are secondary skin lesions. They consists of dried serum and other exudates.

 
Image 1

Papule is a primary skin lesion. It is an elevated solid lesion that is less than 1 cm in diameter. The only distinction between a papule and a nodule is the size (nodule >1cm).

 

Image 3

Pustule is a primary skin lesion. A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. It may occur within a pilosebaceous follicle or a sweat duct or, less often, on glabrous skin. Most commonly due to infections, but some eruptions typically cause sterile pustules.

 

Image 4

Purpura presents as a papule which is a primary skin lesion.

Purpura occurs due to small bleeds from blood vessels into the surrounding skin or mucus membranes. These lesions are bright red to begin with and later progress to purple and finally yellow-brown before disappearing.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female admitted with severe Clostridium difficile colitis received parenteral vancomycin and within 1 hour of initiation of therapy, she developed flushing, erythema, and pruritus involving the face, neck, and upper torso. Antibiotic was immediately withheld, and diphenhydramine was initiated. Which of the following will not help in the prevention or amelioration of such reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of Redman syndrome associated with the parenteral infusion of vancomycin. It is due to a direct toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine. Considering telavancin as a viable option will not ameliorate such reactions as these have also been reported with lipoglycopeptides like telavancin. 

Possible options to ameliorate such reactions:

  • Administering vancomycin by slow infusion (Option-C)
  • Giving a test dose (Option-A)
  • Premedication with antihistamines like diphenhydramine (Option-D)
  • Considering teicoplanin, another glycopeptide antibiotic is a viable option. This type of reaction is not observed with teicoplanin.

Redman or red neck syndrome is a nonallergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin characterized by flushing, erythematous or urticarial reactions, tachycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: A patient on treatment for glaucoma presented with complaints of floaters and flashing lights. He complains of seeing a dark grey curtain move across his field of vision. Which of the following can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of retinal detachment. It is associated with the use of miotics i.e., both cholinergic agonists and anticholinesterase agents.

Miotics produce ciliary body contraction which can lead to altered forces at the vitreous base resulting in retinal tears. Hence, they are to be used with extreme caution in patients who are at risk of developing retinal detachment.

questions.text: The image below shows the EEG recordings during sleep. Which of the following recordings correspond to the stage that is characterized by sawtooth waves and Ponto-geniculo-occipital spikes?
questions.solution:
The stage of sleep is characterized by sawtooth waves and a pontogeniculo-occipital spike (PGO) is REM sleep (EEG recording marked as 4).

Sleep is made up of two physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. REM sleep is characterized by a high level of brain activity. REM sleep refers to rapid, roving eye movements that occur during this stage of sleep and are recorded as an electrooculogram (EOG). The EEG in REM sleep shows rapid, low-voltage activity with sawtooth waves and a pontogeniculo-occipital spike, which refers to large phasic potentials originating in the cholinergic neurons of the pons and passing rapidly to the lateral geniculate body and then to the occipital cortex. 

During REM sleep, except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is increased during this time. 

NREM sleep is composed of stages 1 through 4. About 90 minutes after sleep onset, NREM yields to the first REM episode of the night. Non-REM sleep is divided into four stages:

Stage 1: The transition from wakefulness to sleep. EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) is seen during this stage with vertex sharp waves. There are slow eye movements.

Stage 2: Presence of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz) and K complexes which are negative sharp waves followed by a positive slow wave. There are no eye movements, muscle tone is reduced. (image 2)

Stage 3: Presence of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz). There is a further reduction in muscle tone and arousal, no eye movements. (image 3)

Stage 4: A characteristic pattern of rhythmic slow waves, sometimes referred to as slow-wave sleep. While the occurrence of theta and delta rhythms is normal during sleep. No eye movements, low muscle tone.

Wakefulness: Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is noted. (image 1) Eye movements and eye blinks are present, with high muscle tonic activity and voluntary movements.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of a firm neck swelling associated with dysphagia for the past 3 months. A blood workup shows increased serum calcitonin levels. She reveals that her mother had similar complaints. A biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis which is given below. Which mutation is this condition associated with?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from medullary thyroid carcinoma. RET mutation is associated with this condition. The points that favor the diagnosis are the age of the patient, the presence of neck swelling, elevated calcitonin levels, positive family history, and histopathology image showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma.

Medullary carcinoma tumors of the thyroid are neuroendocrine tumors that are derived from parafollicular C cells, that secrete calcitonin. Most of these cancers occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome: MEN 2A, and MEN 2B. Sporadic cases occur between 40-50 years of age while familial cases occur early. RET mutation plays an important role in the development of both familial and sporadic cancers. 

Patients with sporadic medullary thyroid carcinoma mainly present with a mass in the neck and are associated with dysphagia or hoarseness. Patients with familial syndromes present with symptoms localized to the thyroid or as endocrine neoplasms in other organs.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells which form nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules are present in the stroma. Calcitonin in the tumor cells and stroma is easily demonstratable by immunohistochemistry.

Substituting the values given,

questions.text: Roll over test is done for
questions.solution:
Roll over test:

  • Screening test  for pre eclampsia is done between 28 and 32 weeks.
  • Blood pressure is measured with the patient on her side first and then the patient is asked to roll on her back to check the blood pressure once again.
  • An increase of 20 mm Hg in diastolic pressure from side to back position indicates a positive “roll over test”.
  • About 33% of women with positive “roll over test” developed hypertension later.

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer,  which of the following groups would you target as a part of Kishori Shakti Yojana?
questions.solution:
The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) program is aimed at adolescent girls (11-18 years). 

This program is a component of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme and is a redesign of the already existing Adolescent Girls (AG) scheme.

The objectives of KSY are:

  • To improve the nutrition, health, and development status 
  • To promote awareness on health, hygiene, nutrition, and family care
  • To teach life skills and encourage school attendance
  • To help understand their social environment
  • Aspects aimed at empowerment and enhanced self-perception
  • To help them take initiatives to become productive members of society

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate born at term presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest x-ray of the neonate is shown below. The given congenital heart defect is seen due to the developmental defect of _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the neonate has a cyanotic heart defect and the given x-ray shows figure of 8 or snowman appearance characteristic of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC).

TAPVC refers to a condition in which pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly. This results in anomalous drainage of pulmonary venous blood flow into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with features of congestive heart failure. The patients are irritable and have failure to thrive. 

The following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into the superior vena cava or the left innominate vein.
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. It is shown in the image below.

Other options: (Differentials for cyanotic heart disease) 

Option A: Tricuspid valvular defect is seen in Ebstein's anomaly where the valve is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged right atrium resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly giving a box-shape heart appearance. 

Option C: Aorta and pulmonary artery defects are seen in the transposition of great arteries. Here, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle. The x-ray shows cardiomegaly with cardiac contours which appear like an egg on the side. 

Option D: Truncus arteriosus is a single artery arising from the heart. This single artery supplies pulmonary, systemic, and coronary circulation. It is always associated with a VSD. The truncus overrides the defect and receives blood from both the right and left ventricles.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Trethowan's sign is seen in the x-ray and the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis.

In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by the Hilgenreiner’s line and the Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

questions.text: A final-year student is asked to assess the motor functions of a hemiplegic patient. He asks the patient to dorsiflex and invert both his feet. Which of the muscles marked in the given image performs both these movements?
questions.solution:
The tibialis anterior, which is marked as "4" in the image, produces both dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. It is identified as the muscle that lies immediately adjacent to the tibia and is the most medial muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. 

Tibialis anterior:

Origin - Lateral condyle and lateral surface of the tibial shaft, anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, the deep surface of the deep fascia, and the intermuscular septum between itself and extensor digitorum longus

Insertion - Medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform and adjoining part of the base of the first metatarsal.

Nerve supply - It is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, L4 and L5

Actions - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. The muscle is most active during activities in which both these movements are combined, such as walking.

Other options:

Option A: According to electromyographic research, the fibularis tertius or peroneus tertius works with the extensor digitorum longus and tibialis anterior to produce dorsiflexion of the foot and along with fibularis brevis to produce eversion of the foot.

Option B: The lateral four toes are extended by the extensor digitorum longus. It is an ankle dorsiflexor that synergistically acts with the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and fibularis tertius. It aids in tightening the plantar aponeurosis by working with the extensor hallucis longus.

Option C: Extensor hallucis longus dorsiflexes the foot and extends the great toe.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has been brought to the hospital following blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. On examination, it was found that the structures passing through the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra have been injured. All of the following structures are injured in this case except?
questions.solution:
The most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra is the aortic opening. The right vagus nerve is not injured in the given case as it passes through the oesophageal opening while all these other structures are injured.

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings are the aortic hiatus, the oesophagal hiatus, and the caval hiatus.

The aortic opening is the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening. It is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra and the corresponding intervertebral disc. It is bounded by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, the vertebral column posteriorly, and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly. 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are,

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350mg/dl, pH- 7.2, HCO3-10, pCO2-30. What is the primarymetabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
The patient has a primary metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation (Option B)

Step 1: Observe pH - Patient is in acidosis. 

Step 2: Observe the HCO3 value. The normal value of bicarbonate is 22 - 28 mEq/L, which means that this patient has low levels (10mEq/L) . This is indicative of a primary metabolic acidosis. 
In case of a primary respiratory acidosis, the pCO2 values would have been greater than normal (35 - 45 mmHg). Hence, the answer cannot be Option D.

Step 3: Calculate the expected compensatory fall in pCO2 using Winter’s formula :

             Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2
                                           = (1.5 x 10) + 8 ± 2
                                           = 23 ± 2 mEq/L

This implies that the levels in the patient are higher than expected - suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis.

Note: The likely cause of the condition is diabetic ketoacidosis, as the patient has high blood sugar levels.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of malodorous offensive vaginal discharge. She denies any abdominal pain, dyspareunia, or vaginal itching. Which of the following are the diagnostic criteria for this condition?
  1. Homogenous vaginal discharge
  2. Vaginal pH < 4.5
  3. Positive Whiff test
  4. Clue cells <20%
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an offensive vaginal discharge with no vaginal itching is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. Vaginal pH > 4.5 is the diagnostic criteria. (not < 4.5) and atleast 20% Clue cells should be present i.e. clue cells >20% (not <20%)

 

Bacterial vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in lactobacilli with a 100-fold increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Myco­plasma hominis.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin 2% cream 5 g intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole 0.75% gel 5 g intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is being evaluated for post-menopausal bleeding. Her family history is significant for ovarian and colonic cancers. The pedigree chart plotted is shown below. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm, and a provisional diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia is established. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman with endometrial hyperplasia and an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance of hereditary cancer syndromes (colonic and ovarian) narrows down the diagnosis to Lynch syndrome. It is characterized by defective mismatch repair.

Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers, including endometrial cancer (second most common).

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: A physician visits a patient who is bedridden for the past 5 years. On examination, there is a bedsore in the sacral area with full-thickness skin loss. What is the stage of the pressure sore in this patient?
questions.solution:
Here the patient is having full-thickness skin loss, which is suggestive of stage 3 pressure sore.

Pressure Sores (Bedsores/Pressure ulcers/Decubitus ulcers).

These can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. Common sites for pressure sores include ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral>medial), and occiput.

The grading system for the description of pressure sores:

Category 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Category 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Category 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Category 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint.

Management:

Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the pressure on the area. 

Ulcers of stages I and II often do not require operative measures. The main aim of treatment for pressure ulcers is:

  • To reduce the pressure exerted on the ulcer.
  • Decrease moisture.
  • To keep it as aseptic or least septic as possible.

The ulcer should be cleaned and drained to remove any dead tissue and debris. Good antibiotic cover and hydrocolloid dressing are useful.

Stage 3 and 4 ulcers may require surgical intervention. Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

questions.text: A 17-year-old swimmer presents to your OPD with blurred vision and severe pain in the left eye. On slit-lamp examination, a paracentral ring-shaped lesion is seen. Paracentesis reveals the following finding. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a swimmer with a ring-shaped lesion of the cornea and the image depicting cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis. Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% is the most useful drug in the treatment of this condition.

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes.

It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub while wearing contact lenses, the homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standing groundwater etc.
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern
  • Investigation
    • Staining: Calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
    • Culture: Non-nutrient agar with Escherichia coli overlay

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal Microscopy- may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Histopathology- double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff.
  • Culture: Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. Coli plated on a non-nutrient agar.

 Treatments for this condition include:

  • Diamidines
    • Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %)
    • Hexamidine
  • Aminoglycosides
    • Neomycin
    • Paromycin
  • Imidazoles
    • Clotrimazole
    • Miconazole

Combination therapy with chlorhexidine and polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the most effective against trophozoites and cysts and are recommended as the first line of therapy. Debridement may be warranted in certain conditions.

Chronic refractory cases may require corneal transplantation and unresponsive cases might need to be managed with enucleation. 

The first image shows the ring lesions seen in acanthamoeba keratitis while the second image shows double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with the advanced brain disease. The third image shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts wall of acnathamoeba on plain mount. 

 

Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option 1) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis and spring catarrh which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option 2) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Doxycycline (Option 3) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

questions.text: The condition shown below results from an  Aedes aegypti transmitted flaviviral infection during pregnancy. Identify the virus implicated.
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito borne flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. The symptoms of the infection are similar to dengue and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain.

NCDC Delhi and National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.text: Which is not given in Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Calcium citrate is not used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

The drugs used in the management of Wilson's disease are:

Chelating agents: These drugs bind to copper to form complexes that get excreted in the urine. D-penicillamine and trientine are first-line drugs in symptomatic patients with hepatic diseases.

  • D-penicillamine: It is the recommended drug due to its availability and cost-effectiveness as compared to trientine. Since it is an antagonist to pyridoxine, supplementation of pyridoxine is required. It can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, myasthenia gravis, and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms
  • Trientine: It is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine
  • Tetrathiomolybdate: It has been identified to be effective in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestation

Elemental zinc: 

  • Zinc blocks the intestinal absorption of copper by inducing metallothionein (endogenous chelator in enterocytes)
  • It is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is a second-generation antihistamine?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs. First-generation antihistamines have a strong sedative property and also block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Carbinoxamine
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Chlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Cinnarizine

Second-generation antihistamine- They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine
  • Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine

Important uses of H1 receptor blockers:

  • Allergic rhinitis and urticaria- They block histamine-mediated actions
  • Antinausea and antiemetics- scopolamine and dimenhydrinate are be used in the treatment of motion sickness. Doxylamine is used in the treatment of vomiting in pregnancy.
  • Antiparkinsonism- Diphenhydramine can be used to suppress extrapyramidal symptoms caused due to antipsychotic medications
  • Local anesthesia- Diphenhydramine and promethazine block sodium channels and can act as local anesthetics.

Adverse effects

  • Sedation
  • Antimuscarinic action
  • Orthostatic hypotension due to alpha receptor blockade

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl child is brought for a routine health check-up. On examination, the attending physician hears an additional third heart sound. What is this probably due to?

choices.text: Late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The third heart sound is due to the rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole.

In about one-third of the way through diastole, a soft low-pitched third heart sound is heard in many normal young individuals. It occurs probably due to the vibrations set up by the inrush of blood during the early phase of ventricular diastole, not during ventricular systole.

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, memory loss, and agitation. On examination, he is disoriented and horizontal nystagmus is noted. Which of the following enzyme markers can aid the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
The features of confusion, memory loss, and horizontal nystagmus in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused due to deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). This can be diagnosed by erythrocyte transketolase assay.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin, required for carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is its coenzyme form and is required for the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase 
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

Beriberi - anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness, peripheral neuropathy, and weakness (dry beriberi) or with cardiovascular features like edema, palpitations, breathlessness, distended neck veins (wet beriberi)

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with chronic alcohol abuse which lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

Korsakoff's syndrome is a neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by confabulation and memory defects. Immediate memory is generally maintained but short-term memory is diminished.

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A surgeon working in a community health centre notices that the following suture material shown in the image is the only suture available in stock for use. In which of the following conditions is this suture material not useful?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut which is a yellowish absorbable suture material and cannot be used in procedures like hernia repair that require prolonged support.
