questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pair among the following nail changes with their respective diseases.
questions.solution:
Image 1 is correctly matched. It shows trachonychia, which is most commonly seen in alopecia areata.

Trachyonychia presents as a rough surface affecting the entire nail plate and up to 20 nails (20‐nail dystrophy). It is mainly associated with alopecia areata, psoriasis, and lichen planus.

Other nail findings in alopecia areata:
  • fine stippled pitting of the nails
  • atrophic dystrophy
 
Image 2 shows onychomycosis

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis is the most common pattern of infection. It usually presents as a yellow or white patch of discoloration, at the free edge of the nail plate, and near the lateral nail fold.

 
Image 3 shows nail pitting with subungual oil drops 

Nail pitting is the most frequent change seen in psoriasis. Nail bed disease can be seen as subungual oil drops which are pathognomonic for psoriasis.

 

Image 4 shows the pup tent sign, elevation of nail in shape of tent, which is seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent screening for carcinoma of cervix. A Pap smear was done with the help of the instrument given below. What instrument was used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Cusco speculum.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum that is used to visualize the cervix, perform Pap smears and colposcopic exams, and collect discharge from vaginal fornices for KOH smears. 

Other options:

Option B: Sim speculum is used to look for rectocele and cystocele. The speculum is applied against the anterior vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears (indicates a cystocele or rectocele).  It can also be used for visualization of the vaginal walls. The below image shows Sim's speculum.

 

Option C: Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining(shown below).

Option D: Graves speculum is used to examine a parous woman who has relaxed and collapsing vaginal walls.

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady with G2P1L1 at 34 weeks of gestation came for a regular check-up. On examination, her fundal height corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation. Doppler scan was done and showed the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical arteries, leading to a diagnosis of intrauterine growth restriction.

Other common flow patterns are shown below-

(a): Normal diastolic flow.

(b): Absence of end-diastolic flow seen in IUGR.

(c): Reversal of end-diastolic flow seen in impending IUD.

Umbilical artery vessels:

Characterised by forward, low resistance flow.
As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the resistance indices, so the amount of forward diastolic flow increases.
S/D ratio decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Abnormal flow patterns in umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)
Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise (hence terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks)
Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death (terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age)

Middle cerebral artery:

This will show increased diastolic velocity in fetus with hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

questions.text:
You are planning to administer spinal anesthesia to a young female. Which of the following needles would be the least suitable for reducing the risk of a post-dural puncture headache?

G- gauge
questions.solution:
Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is most commonly seen with 22G Quincke needle (22G has a larger diameter than 25G). So it should be avoided in cases with a higher risk of PDPH.

The spinal needles given in the image are-

A- Quincke spinal needle 

B- Whitacre spinal needle

 

Types of spinal needles: 

Cutting needle Non-cutting (Splitting, pencil point, blunt) needle
Cut the dura Split the dura
Hence the higher incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to cerebrospinal fluid leak Hence, a lower incidence of PDPH
Technically less challenging as loss of resistance is well appreciated during lumbar puncture Technically more challenging as loss of resistance is not well appreciated
Eg: Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin  Eg: Whitacre, Sprotte

 

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text:
Match the causative organism for the lesions given below.

A. Pox virus

B. Herpes simplex virus

C. Human papilloma virus

D. Human herpes virus 7
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Image 1 shows herpetic whitlow caused by herpes simplex virus.

It is often contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus; it is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions.

On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Image 2 shows verruca vulgaris or common wart caused by human papilloma virus 2 (HPV-2) but is also closely related to types 27 and 57 as well as types 1 and 4.

  • Common warts are usually asymptomatic.
  • These present as firm papules with a rough horny surface.
  • These are most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers, and, in children on the knees, but may occur anywhere on the skin.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed: new lesions along the sites of trauma.
  • Products containing salicylic acid with or without lactic acid are effective patient-applied treatments. Cryotherapy can also be effectively used for periungual warts.
  • Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic feature of koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis. (image given below)

Image 3 shows a herald patch, which is covered by fine scales. It is seen in pityriasis rosea, most commonly caused by human herpes virus-7.

  • Pityriasis rosea is an acute self‐limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults and characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms.
  • HHV‐7 is detected slightly more frequently than HHV‐6, but often both viruses are found.
  • The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch, which is larger and more conspicuous than the lesions of the later eruption and is usually situated on the thigh or upper arm, trunk, or neck and covered by fine scales.
  • After an interval, which is usually between 5 and 15 days, the general eruption begins to appear in crops and consists of discrete oval lesions,
    dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery‐grey scales.
  • The center tends to clear and assumes a wrinkled, atrophic appearance and a tawny color, with a marginal collarette of scale attached peripherally, with the free edge of the scale internally called a hanging curtain sign.
  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of cleavage parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.
  • The common asymptomatic and self‐limiting cases require no treatment.

Image 4 shows small pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center—lesions of molluscum contagiosum caused by pox virus. 

  • The age of peak incidence is reported as between 2 and 5 years.
  • The incubation period is variously estimated at 14 days to 6 months.
  • In children, it is mainly caused by Type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1).
  • PseudoKoebner phenomenon is seen - new lesions develop along line of trauma.
  • There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection.
  • Sexually transmitted Molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, or curettage and expression

Image: Keratinocytes of stratum malpighii become enlarged and acquire eosinophilic inclusion bodies—Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies that contain virus particles.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a specimen received after staging laparotomy for an ovarian mass revealed the following. Which of the following tumor is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histological finding denotes Psammoma bodies which are histopathological findings of ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma.

They are concentrically calcified basophilic structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Its presence per se does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are commonly seen in certain tumors such as:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Ovarian tumors: Papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas, in the central nervous system
  • Peritoneal and Pleural Mesothelioma
  • Prolactinoma of the pituitary
  • Lung Adenocarcinoma

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing functions. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair, also known as Manchester's operation, is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix, and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence, subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.

questions.text: A 14-day-old baby is being evaluated in the pediatric department for ambiguous genitalia. On examination, the baby is dehydrated. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Karyotyping evaluation demonstrates  46, XX chromosomal pattern. Measurement of which of the following will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (classical 21-hydroxylase deficiency). Measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis in this case.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Children usually present with salt-wasting crises as seconded by dehydration with hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

The diagnosis is confirmed by markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. The most commonly performed neonatal screening programs screen only for 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in dried blood obtained by heel stick and absorbed on filter paper cards. Also, these same cards are screened in parallel for other congenital conditions, such as hypothyroidism and phenylketonuria.

Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment. Patients with salt-wasting and virilizing forms are treated with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone. Surgical treatment is usually done between 2-6 months of age for significantly virilized females.

Males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency who have had inadequate corticosteroid therapy may develop testicular adrenal rest tumors. These usually regress following increased steroid dosage.

The image below summarizes the pathway involved in steroid hormonal production and the pearl summarizes the various non-classical forms of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. 

Note:  In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, as a result of the deficient enzyme(21-hydroxylase), there is an impaired conversion of 17-hydroxyprogesterone to 11-deoxycortisol. This results in the overproduction of adrenal androgen precursors and adrenal androgens. The diagnostic hormone 17-hydroxyprogesterone is markedly elevated in CAH. If the 17-hydroxyprogesterone level is markedly elevated (>10,000 ng/dL), the diagnosis of classic CAH is likely, whereas levels >2000 ng/dL but <10,000 ng/dL typically reflect non-classic disease.

Other options:

Option A: Although 21-hydroxylase is the deficient enzyme in this condition. Its level is not routinely measured to confirm the diagnosis.

Options C and D: 17-hydroxylase and 11β hydroxylase deficiency generally present with salt retention crises and hypertension.

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched pair among the following substances of abuse with their respective feature of chronic use.
questions.solution:
Image 3 is a picture of heroin, which is incorrectly matched with amotivational syndrome that is a feature of chronic use of cannabis.

Heroin (an opioid) :

  • It is known as morphinism/morphinomania
  • Addicts have dry skin and show abscesses or scars of healed abscesses. Sometimes tattooing from needles may be seen.
  • Larger doses lead to disinterest and recurring periods of depression.
  • The patient becomes restless and irritable and sleep is disturbed by dreams or there is insomnia.
  • Loss of memory, mental fatigue, and gradual intellectual and moral deterioration occur.
  • Hallucinations may occur.
  • Constipation, contracted pupils, anorexia, emaciation, and weakness and impotence are frequent.
  • Sudden cessation of opioid use in dependent pregnant women may be life-threatening to the foetus.

Image 1 :

Cannabis - Running amok: Heavy marijuana users may develop manic or paranoid psychosis. The person may run amok, i.e., he develops a psychic disturbance marked by a period of depression, followed by violent attempts to kill people (impulse to murder)

  • When used in excess, it causes degeneration of the central nervous system and insanity.
  • Chronic use reduces serum testosterone and sperm count and is associated with gynecomastia.
  • There is loss of appetite, weakness, wasting, tremors, sleepy facial expression, vacant look, red eyes, impotence, and moral and mental deterioration.
  • Rarely do users become insane (hashish insanity), and may suffer from auditory and visual hallucinations and delusions of persecution.
  • Chronic use may lead to amotivational syndrome with loss of age-appropriate behavior, like lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities at home and school.
  • Marijuana is a potential carcinogen.

Image 2 :

LSD - Flashback phenomenon: This may occur days, weeks or even months after the ingestion of a dose, and the person experiences a recurrence of the emotional and psychological aspects of the previous 'LSD' trip. These delayed recurring symptoms may lead to eccentric behavior, suicide, or even homicide. Repeated use by an addict can lead to permanent psychosis.

 Image 4 :

Cocaine - Magnan's symptom: Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs is characteristic, in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin. It gives rise to itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination) with resultant excoriation, leading to irregular scratches and ulcers.

  • Chronic use is also known as cocainism, cocainophagia or cocainomania.
  • It causes :
    • Digestive disturbances
    • Anorexia
    • Salivation
    • Tachycardia
    • Tachyapnoea
    • Insomnia.
  • Tongue and teeth turn black.
  • A manic, paranoid, or depressive psychosis may develop (cocaine psychosis or excited delirium)
  • Complications :
    • Persistent rhinitis
    • Nasal erosions
    • Sinusitis
    • Chronic cough
    • Bronchitis
    • Sniffing habit leads to ulceration of the nasal septum
    • Degeneration of the central nervous system occurs, and the patient may suffer from hallucinations, convulsions, delirium, and insanity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with the following deformity. She complains of joint pain and stiffness in the fingers for 5-6 years. She reports that stiffness is more in the early morning and improves on performing household activities. What is the most common extra-articular manifestation seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with image showing swan neck deformity (hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint) is classically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules. 

Subcutaneous nodules are generally firm, non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae. They develop in areas that are subjected to repeated trauma or irritation such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. Nodules can also develop in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Infection, gangrene and malignant transformation can be rarely seen with subcutaneous nodules.

Other extraarticular manifestations seen in rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Sjogren syndrome - it presents with keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis - it presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis
  • Pulmonary -  
    • Pleuritis - most common pulmonary manifestation
    • Interstitial lung diseases
  • Cardiac - 
    • Pericarditis - most common cardiac manifestation
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Coronary artery disease
  • Hematologic - 
    • Normochromic normocytic anemia - most common hematologic abnormality 
    • Felty's syndrome - is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular rheumatoid arthritis. It is a rare manifestation
    • Lymphoma

Patients developing extra-articular manifestations are associated with risk factors such as: History of smoking, early onset of physical disability, rheumatoid factor positive and anti-CCP antibody positive.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby presents with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when weaning was started with fruit juice. Which of the following can give a positive reaction in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the above clinical features after the initiation of fruit juice (rich in fructose) suggests a disorder of fructose metabolism. Seliwanoff's reagent gives a positive reaction in this condition.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause glycogen accumulation in the liver and associated hypoglycemia.

Symptoms occur when sucrose (fructose+glucose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Fructose is also excreted in the urine. This gives a positive reducing sugar test (Benedict's test), a positive test for furfural derivatives, and specifically a positive Seliwanoff's test (for fructose). Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will immediately relieve the symptoms

Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar. The blue color indicates the absence of sugar in the urine. The green precipitate means 0.5%, yellow (1%), orange (1.5%) and red indicates 2% or more sugar (1% means 1 g per 100 ml). 

Furfural test: Monosaccharides when treated with concentrated sulphuric acid undergo dehydration with the removal of 3 molecules of water. Hexoses give hydroxymethylfurfural and pentoses give furfural. The furfural derivative can condense with phenolic compounds to give colored products. This forms the basis of the Molisch test. It is a general test for carbohydrates.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pain and stiffness in the small joints of the hands. On examination, there is swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints but the distal interphalangeal joints are normal. There is no involvement of the skin, hair, or nails. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The characteristic involvement of metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints with sparing of distal interphalangeal joints in a 34-year-old female is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially- metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved. Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement is usually due to coexistent osteoarthritis.
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity - Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint
  • Boutonnière deformity - Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint,
  • Z-line deformity - Subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint 
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger)
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Laboratory investigations - Detection of Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies help in differentiating this condition from other forms of arthritis.

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Other options-

Option (A): Gout is characterized by episodic acute arthritis or chronic arthritis due to the deposition of monosodium urate(MSU) crystals in the joints and connective tissue. It commonly affects postmenopausal women and middle-aged to elderly men. The metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP) of the first toe is commonly involved. Other joints that are commonly affected include the tarsal joints, ankle, and knee.

Option (B): Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis with a high prevalence in the elderly population. Commonly involved joints are the knee, hip, first MTP, and the cervical and lumbosacral spine. In the hands, the DIP and PIP joints and the base of the thumb are commonly involved. The wrist, elbow, and ankle are usually spared. 

Option (D): Psoriatic arthritis- In most cases psoriasis precedes arthritis but in some cases, both of them present in a span of 1 year or arthritis precedes psoriasis. There can be involvement of DIP and PIP joints and the joint involvement tend to follow "ray "distribution. Ray distribution refers to the involvement of all the joints of one finger while the adjacent finger is totally spared. Nail changes in the affected fingers are a differentiating feature of this condition.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man has an extreme and irrational fear of heights and prefers to live on the ground floor. The thought of attending an event on the terrace of a hotel brings about intense anxiety. What are the defense mechanisms involved in this condition?
  1. Displacement
  2. Dissociation
  3. Avoidance
  4. Symbolization
  5. Reaction formation
questions.solution:
Defense mechanisms involved in this scenario are displacement, avoidance, and symbolization - 1,3,4 (Option A).

The clinical scenario of extreme fear of heights points toward acrophobia and the defense mechanisms involved in phobias are displacement, symbolization, and avoidance.

A phobia can be described as a fear that is irrational and out of proportion to the stimulus. Defense mechanisms mediate an individual's reaction to emotional conflicts and stressors. In displacement, the conflict or emotions are displaced from the actual cause to a less threatening, irrel­evant object or situation. 

The primary source of the conflict may have a direct associative connec­tion with the phobic object or situation that symbolizes it. This object is something the person can avoid and this protects the person from the anxiety attached to the original object or idea, which is the defense mechanism of symbolization.

The phobic situation or the object is usually something that the person can avoid. With the defense mechanism of avoidance, the person can escape the anxiety associated with it. 

Behavioral therapy is the most effective treatment for phobias. Insight-oriented therapy, virtual therapy, and exposure therapy are also used for the treatment of phobic disorders and specific phobias. β-receptor blockers can be used for the treatment of specific phobias, particularly if it is associated with panic attacks. Benzodiazepines can also be used but the chronic nature of the disease limits its effect. Paroxetine and sertraline can be used to manage social anxiety. 

Dissociation is the splitting of mental contents in clusters from conscious awareness. This allows the individual to support two contradictory truths while not being aware of them. An extreme manifestation of this mechanism is seen in dissociative identity disorder. 

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

 

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infection of the Bartholin gland i.e. Bartholin abscess. Bartholin glands are not homologous to the male glands of Littre.

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties.  

The male glands of Littre are homologous to mucous secreting periurethral glands in females.

Clinical conditions associated with the Bartholin gland are Bartholin cyst and Bartholin abscess. The cyst is caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation due to infection. An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess.

These infections commonly involve the duct and are most commonly sexually transmitted. It is generally polymicrobial. (Option A)Bacteroides species, Peptostreptococcus species, Escherichia coli, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are frequently encountered in the culture of purulent drainage. Less often, Chlamydia trachomatis may be identified.

Larger cysts can cause vaginal discomfort and dyspareunia. Abscesses will show erythema with tenderness. The cystic swelling and the abscess are both fluctuant. Bartholin cysts are transilluminating due to the clear fluid they contain. 

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment:
    1. Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    2. Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management. (Option C) The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:
      • Simple procedure
      • Can be done even under local anesthesia.
      • Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).
      • The postoperative complication is almost nil.
      • Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 
    3. Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement: A deflated Word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    4. Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

In older women with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy. (Option D)

questions.text: An elderly woman who underwent a hip replacement surgery 1 week back now complains of hemoptysis and breathlessness. On examination, she complains of pain in her calf on pressing it, and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. The D-dimer levels are found to be elevated. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of deep vein thrombosis, breathlessness, and hemoptysis after major surgery with elevated levels of D-dimer suggest that the patient has a pulmonary embolism. The next step in the management of this patient is to perform a CT pulmonary angiography.

Approach to a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) should be suspected in a patient who complains of sudden breathlessness and hemoptysis after prolonged immobilization. Well's point score helps to estimate the clinical likelihood of PE. When patients' chances of PE are high, the patient should be assessed for D-dimer levels. Normal levels of D-dimer rule out the possibility of PE. If the D-dimer levels are elevated, then the chances of pulmonary embolism are very high and the patient should undergo imaging to confirm the diagnosis.

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It can provide exquisite detail, with ≤1 mm of resolution during a short breath-hold. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. In patients who do not have a pulmonary embolism, it can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Because of the invasive nature of pulmonary angiography (option B) and availability of chest CT scans, it is not commonly used in the diagnosis of PE. It is reserved for patients with technically unsatisfactory chest CTs and for those for whom an interventional procedure such as catheter-directed thrombolysis is planned.

Lung scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Small particulate aggregates of albumin labeled with a gamma-emitting radionuclide are injected intravenously and are trapped in the pulmonary capillary bed. The perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

MR pulmonary angiography is a reliable test to identify deep vein thrombosis. It may detect large proximal PE, but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram (option D). Therefore, it is not a reliable test to detect PE. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, you note flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb. Which of the following radiographic findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip which is represented in radiograph 3 of the given image.

Anterior dislocation of the hip is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident.

On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. It is also slightly flexed. Additionally, a prominent anterior bulge will be present either in the pubic region or in the groin region.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as:

  • Type I - Superior or pubic
  • Type II - Inferior or obturator

Radiological findings include:

  • The displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side
  • As the thigh is externally rotated lesser trochanter is more prominent
  • A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The given image shows a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Other options:

Radiograph 1-  Intertrochanteric fracture of the femur- This is usually sustained following a fall or RTA and the leg is short and externally rotated. Clinical findings are more marked than the neck of femur fractures.

Radiograph 2- Posterior dislocation of the hip- This is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and in this condition, the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • The femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

Radiograph 4- Fracture neck of the femur - This can present with shortening and external rotation of the limb.

Radiological findings include:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in the Shenton's line

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient presents to the casualty with complaints of sudden onset of pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a palpable tympanic swelling in the left side of the abdomen. X-ray abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the X-ray are suggestive of cecal volvulus. It is differentiated from sigmoid volvulus as there is only a single air-fluid level and the lower end of the dilatation is not pointed to the pelvis.

Cecal volvulus can only occur when the cecum and ascending colon arc on a mesentery. This is often associated with a degree of malrotation. It is commonly seen in females of 4th and 5th decade. They present with features of acute intestinal obstruction. Initially, the obstruction may be partial and the patient can pass feces and flatus.

A palpable tympanic swelling in the midline or the left side may be seen in 25% of the cases.

Radiological findings include cecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. CT shows a whirl sign, which is also seen in the midgut volvulus.

If there are no concerns of ischemia, a barium enema can be used to confirm the diagnosis. The characteristic findings include the absence of barium in the cecum and bird beak deformity.

Other options:

Sigmoid volvulus- It is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Sigmoid volvulus is differentiated from a cecal volvulus by its ahaustral wall and the lower end pointing to the pelvis. Abdominal radiographs will show a large, inverted U-shaped dilated loop of the colon, often with two air-fluid levels one in each limb of the loop.

Specific radiographic signs:

  • Coffee bean sign
  • Frimann-Dahl's sign - three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction
  • Bird of prey sign
  • Absent rectal gas

The radiograph given below is that of sigmoid volvulus.

Differences between small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

  Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No. of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

An erect radiograph of small bowel obstruction with multiple air-fluid levels is shown below.

The dilated proximal small bowel is predominantly gas filled with a few air fluid levels.

More distally, the small bowel is fluid-filled and bubbles of gas are trapped between the valvulae conniventes, producing a chain of bubbles. This is known as a "string of beads" appearance.

Intussusception - It occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The characteristic clinical triad is pain, red-currant jelly stools, and palpable sausage-shaped mass.

Radiological findings:

  • Target sign, pseudokidney sign, and crescent in a doughnut sign in USG
  • Coiled spring appearance on double contrast barium enema

The image given below shows the coiled spring appearance-

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

questions.text: A couple who have been diagnosed with asymptomatic COVID-19 have been advised to undergo home quarantine. They have been advised to perform the 6-minute walk test every 6-8 hours to assess cardiopulmonary function. Which of the following is not a scenario where the patient is labelled as "positive for 6-minute walk"?

choices.text: Feeling lightheaded at the end of the test
A recording of 93% saturation during the test
Shortness of breath during the test
A drop of saturation from 97% to 95% at the end of the test

questions.solution:
A drop of saturation from 97% to 95% at the end of the test does not classify as "positive" for the six minute walk test.

A 6-minute walk test is an established simple clinical test to assess cardiopulmonary exercise tolerance. This test is used to unmask hypoxia. A patient with a pulse oximeter attached to his finger is asked to walk in the confines of his room for 6 minutes continuously.

The patient is labelled as "positive" for the 6-minute walk test in the following situations :

  • Any drop in saturation below 94%
  • An absolute drop of more than 3% to 5%
  • Feeling unwell (lightheaded, short of breath)

while performing the test or at the end of 6 minutes are significant findings. Such patients are labeled as positive for the 6-minute walk test.

Patients with a positive 6-minute walk test may progress to become hypoxic and hence early admission to the hospital [for observation and oxygen supplementation] is recommended. The test can be repeated every 6 to 8 hours of monitoring in-home setting. It should not be done in patients older than 70 years, those with uncontrolled asthma, pregnant patients

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented to the clinic with difficulty in vision. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for which she has been on medication for many years along with drugs for the management of her diabetes and hypertension. Fundus examination of the patient shows the following finding. Which of the following drug could have caused this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the bull’s eye maculopathy which can be caused by hydroxychloroquine. This patient's history of being treated for rheumatoid arthritis is the most probable reason for the lesion.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a "bulls-eye" appearance to the macula.

Hydroxychloroquine, which is generally used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, toxicity causes bull’s eye maculopathy. Chloroquine binds to melanin in the retinal pigment epithelium, causing cytotoxic effects.

Causes of bull’s eye maculopathy include:

  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Congenital cone dystrophy

Other adverse effects of chloroquine:

  • Nail bed and mucosal membrane discoloration
  • Irreversible retinopathy
  • Ototoxicity
  • Toxic myopathy
  • Cardiopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy

 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Given below is a dissected heart specimen of a middle-aged man showing the internal structure of the right atrium and ventricle. The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the remnants of which of the following structures respectively?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the limbus and floor of fossa ovalis, which are the remnants of septum secundum and septum primum respectively.

Fossa ovalis is an oval-shaped depression in the septal wall of the right atrium just above the opening of the inferior vena cava. It marks the location of the embryonic foramen ovale. 

  • The floor of fossa ovalis is the remnant of the septum primum.
  • The limbus of the fossa ovalis is the prominent upper margin of the fossa ovalis. It is a remnant of the septum secundum.

Related Pearl: Development of Interatrial septum

  • The Inter-atrial septum develops from Septum Primum and Septum Secundum
  • The septum primum begins to develop at 28 days. It is a thin, crescentic fold of endocardium that arises craniodorsally and grows down to the AV cushions, leaving an ostium primum below its free edge.
  • Septum primum fuses with the AV cushions at approximately 35 days, obliterating the ostium primum.
  • The ostium secundum is an opening in the upper part of the septum primum. It forms at about 33 days, i.e., before the ostium primum closes.
  • The septum secundum is a thick muscular septum that arises to the right of the septum primum. It grows from the roof of the atrium but does not reach the AV cushion. The gap between the two septa is known as foramen ovale.
  • After birth, the foramen ovale is obliterated by the fusion of the septum primum with the septum secundum.
  • In terms of adult anatomy, the annulus ovalis/limbus of fossa ovalis is the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the floor of fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child comes with a high-grade fever for the past four days. On examination, you also notice conjunctival redness, strawberry tongue, erythematous feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy. RT-PCR test done is positive for COVID - 19. Laboratory investigations shows ESR - 71mm and CRP - 22 mg/L. Panel done for tropical infections is negative. Which of the following is best suited to treat this patient?

choices.text: IV Methylprednisolone, IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous) and antimicrobials
IV Methylprednisolone and IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous)

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing a child with unremitting fever >3 days, testing positive for COVID along with conjunctival redness, strawberry tongue, erythematous feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy is indicative of Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) with Kawasaki Disease (KD) phenotype which is treated with IV Methylprednisolone and IVIG.

Multi-System Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a new syndrome in children characterized by unremitting fever >38ºC and epidemiological linkage with SARS-CoV-2

Diagnostic criteria (WHO) :

  • Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days
  • And any two of the following:
    • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or muco-cutaneous inflammation signs (oral, hands or feet)
    • Hypotension or shock
    • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP)
    • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
    • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)
  • And elevated markers of inflammation such as ESR (>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin
  • And no other obvious microbial cause of inflammation, including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes
  • And evidence of recent COVID-19 infection (RT-PCR, antigen test or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19

Alternative diagnoses that must be excluded before making a diagnosis of MIS-C :

  • Tropical fevers (malaria, dengue, scrub typhus, enteric fever)
  • Toxic shock syndrome (staphylococcal or streptococcal)
  • Bacterial sepsis

MIS-C with Kawasaki Disease (KD) phenotype is characterised by fever, conjunctival redness, oropharyngeal findings (red and/or cracked lips, strawberry tongue), rash, swollen and/or erythematous hands and feet and cervical lymphadenopathy.

Management of MIS-C Kawasaki Phenotype :

IVIG 2 gm/kg over 12-16 hours (max. 100 g), and IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is administered. If symptoms persist for 48-72 hours of treatment, or if early worsening an expert is consulted for biologicals.

IVIG is to be given slower (over up to 48 hours) in children with cardiac failure/ fluid overload and steroids are tapered over 2-3 weeks with clinical and CRP monitoring.

A combination of IV Methylprednisolone, IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous) and antimicrobials are used to treat MIS-C with shock.

Only IV Methylprednisolone is used to treat MIS-C without shock.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. Biopsy of the lymph node is done showing findings in the picture. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Lab findings are given below. Which among the following is the cell of origin in this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10gm/dl

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing generalized painless lymphadenopathy, immunotyping showing CD5, CD20 and cyclin D1 with histopathology showing irregular nuclear contours of the medium-sized lymphoma cells and the presence of pink histiocytes is suggestive of Mantle Cell Lymphoma which has naive B cells as its cell of origin.

Mantle cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1.

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

The most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy. Symptoms related to the involvement of the spleen (present in ~50% of cases) and gut are also common. Frequent sites of extranodal involvement include the bone marrow, spleen, liver, and gut. Occasionally, mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions (lymphomatoid polyposis). The prognosis is poor; the median survival is only 3 to 4 years.

Histopathology shows nodular Mantle Cell Lymphoma with irregular nuclear contours of the medium-sized lymphoma cells and the presence of pink histiocytes.

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively. In most cases the nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

Immunophenotype. Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. These cells are CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, C22+, CD23-, CD 5+.

Other Options:

Germinal center B cell / Post germinal centre B cell is the cell of origin in Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Germinal center B cell is also the cell of origin for Burkitt's lymphoma and Follicular lymphoma.

Memory B cells are the cells of origin in Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma, Hairy cell leukemia, and in some cases Small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia (SLL/CLL).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female patient presents with weakness and dizziness. She has low blood pressure, but no diarrhea or fever. She has a history of vitiligo and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Her examination findings and investigations are given below. Which of the following is the reason for her adrenal insufficiency?

Lab results show: 

Cortisol level- low, ACTH level- raised

Serum Electrolytes Values Normal Range
Sodium (mmol/L)  130  135-145 
Chloride (mmol/L)  100 95-105
Potassium (mmol/L)  5.3 3.5-5 
Bicarbonate (mmol/L)  20 18-22
questions.solution:
This patient with weakness, low blood pressure, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and raised ACTH levels with decreased cortisol levels points to a diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency. The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency is autoimmune adrenal insufficiency, especially in this patient as she has other underlying autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis and vitiligo. 

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Decreased cortisol and elevated ACTH Decreased cortisol and ACTCH
Hyperpigmentation present Hyperpigmentation absent
Causes: Autoimmune, TB, adrenal metastasis Causes: Chronic glucocorticoid therapy, pituitary lesions


Primary adrenal insufficiency:

The common causes of Addison’s disease are:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries
  • Autoimmune (Idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries
  • Metastasis to adrenal glands

Clinical features - lethargy, weight loss, nausea/vomiting, hyperpigmentation in an exposed area, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, eosinophilia, and hypoglycemia may be seen.

Diagnosis - Cosyntropin stimulation test, plasma ACTH and cortisol levels, plasma renin and aldosterone levels.

Treatment - glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and androgen replacement therapy.

Other options:

Options B and D - are both causes of secondary adrenal insufficiency. 

Option C - Adrenal metastasis is rare compared to autoimmune causes. Additionally, the metastatic disease will have signs of the primary tumor, weight loss, etc.

  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma

  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole

  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)

  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease
