questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the casualty after sustaining multiple injuries during a landslide. He was trapped there for 3-4 hours before the rescue team found him. Imaging revealed multiple rib fractures, pneumothorax, and hemothorax. Laboratory studies revealed elevated serum creatinine, and creatinine phosphokinase levels, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of prolonged entrapment, clinical features, and laboratory findings are all suggestive of crush syndrome. 

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Clinical features:

  • The affected limb is pulseless, red, and swollen
  • In some cases, sensation and muscle power may be lost.

Management of crush syndrome

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure.
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed.
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis.
  • Aggressive management of the open wound.

Other options:

Fat embolism: It is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. It is usually seen 2-3 days following the injury. Clinical features include tachycardia, rise in temperature, breathlessness, and mild mental confusion. Petechial hemorrhage on the trunk, axilla, and conjunctival folds are pathognomonic.

Hemorrhagic shock: It is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Acute compartment syndrome: It refers to an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures(commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intracompartmental pressures.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement about pituitary gonadotropins.

LH- Luteinizing hormone

FSH- follicle-stimulating hormone

choices.text: LH levels are lower than FSH during the reproductive years
LH and FSH are strikingly low after menopause
FSH: LH ratio is typically elevated before menarche
The LH surge magnitude decreases after puberty

questions.solution:
FSH: LH ratio is typically elevated before menarche.

GnRH is initially secreted in low-frequency pulses early in puberty, which favors FSH secretion initially. FSH: LH ratio is typically increased in the premenarchal girl. Later in puberty, the GnRH pulsatile frequency increases with a greater rise in LH surges, leading to the establishment of the adult pattern of gonadotropin release. 

Increased gonadotropin levels stimulate estradiol production from the ovaries. This in turn prompts the growth spurt, maturation of the female internal and external genitalia, and development of female secondary sexual characteristics - thelarche, pubarche, adrenarche. Increased gonadotropin levels ultimately lead to ovulation and subsequent menses - menarche.

During the reproductive years, LH levels exceed FSH levels, and the FSH: LH ratio gets inverted.

After menopause, the ovary contains only a few follicles, leading to low levels of estrogen and inhibin. LH and FSH levels are subsequently elevated due to loss of the negative feedback from estrogen and inhibin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding chest compression during CPR in an infant?

choices.text: Depth should be 1/5th of the depth of the infant’s chest
Done 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum

questions.solution:
The depth of the chest compression in a one-month-old child receiving CPR is 1/3rd the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100-120/min (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • The depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast.
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

The compression-to-ventilation ratio for pediatric CPR depends on the number of rescuers present:

  • For a single rescuer: 30:2 (30 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)
  • For two rescuers: 15:2 (15 chest compressions followed by 2 breaths)

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain radiating to the back. Investigations revealed elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. An abdominal X-ray showed the colon-cut off sign.  Which of the following criteria uses CT to stage the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the abdominal radiograph showing the colon cut-off sign are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar Scoring is used for staging the severity of acute pancreatitis based on CT findings.

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks), and Cullen’s sign (bluish discoloration around the umbilicus) can be present.

The Grey Turner sign is shown below:

Cullen's sign is shown below:

The below abdominal x-ray shows an abrupt transition from distended to collapsed colon just beyond the splenic flexure. This is known as a colon cut-off sign.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Other options-

Option A: Modified Glasgow score uses 8 laboratory findings to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis (within 48 hours of treatment onset). It is not a CT-based scoring system.

Option C: APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation score) is another clinical tool that assesses the risk of mortality and predicts prolonged intensive care treatment. It is also not CT-based.

Option D: Ranson's criteria uses 11 clinical and laboratory findings at admission and after 48 hours to assess clinical severity. It does not include CT scan findings.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points. 

CTSI score 0-3: Mild pancreatitis

CTSI score 4-6: Moderate pancreatitis

CTSI score 7-10: Severe pancreatitis

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL

questions.text: A 1-day old newborn is examined for complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting for the past one hour. He was last breastfed 90 minutes back.  He has not passed meconium yet. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and weighed 3.3 kg. The pregnancy was uneventful for the mother apart from severe hyperemesis gravidarum in the first trimester which required hospitalization. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is distended. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Perform echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest  and spine
Start IV fluids and parenteral nutrition

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the radiograph showing the presence of a double bubble sign is strongly suggestive of duodenal atresia. Upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands are features of Down's syndrome which has an association with duodenal atresia. The next best and immediate step in the management of duodenal atresia is to perform an orogastric aspiration to decompress the intestinal contents. 

Associated conditions:

  • It is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome (as in this baby), maternal polyhydramnios and cardiac malformations.
  • There is an association with VACTERL defects
  • It is also associated with malformations of the hepatobiliary system such as the annular pancreas and biliary atresia.
  • Other bowel atresias, including jejunal atresia, ileal atresia, and rectal atresia

Duodenal atresia:

Duodenal atresia is caused due to failure of recanalization or partial recanalization of the duodenum or failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage. The range of anatomic variants includes duodenal stenosis, mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity), two ends separated by a fibrous cord, and complete separation with a gap within the duodenum. 

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign.

Clinical findings:

Symptoms:

In most cases, the duodenal obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater (85%); therefore, infants present with bilious emesis. In patients with a mucosal web, the symptoms of postprandial emesis may occur later in life. Clinically, babies usually present with features of intestinal obstruction soon after birth if the atresia is not identified in the prenatal period. There may be delayed passage of meconium. 

Signs:

On examination, the upper abdomen is distended with a scaphoid lower abdomen. 

Investigations

These include abdominal radiographs that show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be considered not only to confirm the diagnosis of duodenal stenosis or atresia but also to exclude midgut volvulus, which would constitute a surgical emergency.

Excessive bilious vomiting can cause hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria, particularly if there is a delay in hydration. Thus, Arterial blood gas analysis is generally undertaken to know the fluid-electrolyte status. 

Pediatric CT plays a very limited if any, role in the diagnosis and evaluation of duodenal atresia.  However, a CT reconstruction may allow for further evaluation of bowel layout in confusing cases

Treatment:

  • The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression.
  • IV fluids and parenteral nutrition are started to prevent acid-base imbalance. In the given case, ABG is within normal limits. Thus, gastric decompression takes priority over IV rehydration. (Option-D)
  • Echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest and spine should be performed to evaluate for associated anomalies. (Option-A)
  • Definitive correction of the atresia is usually postponed until life-threatening anomalies are evaluated and treated. The typical surgical repair for duodenal atresia is duodenoduodenostomy (Option-B). This procedure is also preferred in cases of the concomitant or isolated annular pancreas.

 

Option B: Jejunal atresia on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with complaints of excessive bleeding during menstruation, accompanied by a feeling of heaviness in her lower abdomen. Her periods last for 8-10 days and are associated with the passage of clots. An ultrasound of her pelvis reveals a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic mass. She has completed her family and does not wish to preserve her fertility. Which among the following drugs are not helpful in shrinkage of this tumor prior to surgery?
  1. Mifepristone
  2. Leuprolide
  3. Goserelin
  4. Tibolone
  5. Misoprostol
questions.solution:
The clinical case described points to a diagnosis of uterine fibroid (leiomyoma), and the drugs tibolone and misoprostol (4 and 5) do not reduce the size. The ultrasound image with complaints of prolonged and heavy menstrual bleeding with pelvic heaviness are features of uterine fibroids.

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, triptorelin, nafarelin
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil

Other medical methods used in the treatment of fibroids:

  • Levonorgestrel Intrauterine device - controls bleeding effectively
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)
  • Tranexamic acid 
  • Iron therapy for anemia
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss, without interfering with the size of the fibroid. 

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery Embolization - Angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Tibolone is a synthetic derivative of 19-nortestosterone and has a weak oestrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic action. It is used as add-back therapy to reduce the side effects of GnRH therapy by counteracting the antiestrogenic effects. They do not interfere with the size of the fibroid. It elevates the mood, relieves the vasomotor symptoms, improves the sex drive, and reduces bone resorption. Its main action is cardioprotection by reducing the level of triglycerides.

Misoprostol is a prostaglandin (PGE1) and is used in cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in medical termination of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

 

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A patient was brought dead to the casualty. Fundoscopy exhibits the sign as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most accurate inference regarding the time of death?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows the Kevorkian sign. Hence, the most accurate time of death is less than 1 hour.

Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels and lasts for about 1 hour. This means that the patient had died within the preceding hour. 

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels and occurs due to loss of blood pressure. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea: Dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous:  Linear increase up to 100 hours following death.
  • Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye which becomes brown and then black. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: A male sewer worker had an on-and-off fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice, and purple-blue spots on his skin. He developed hematuria and neck stiffness soon after that and was found to have deranged hepatic and renal parameters. He succumbed to death. A  hepatic tissue section is stained as shown below. What special stain has been used to visualize the specimen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis caused by Leptospires which are best visualized in tissue sections by staining using Levaditi's silver impregnation method.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species. Rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to severe fatal disease, referred to as Weil's disease. Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury. Faget sign (temperature pulse dissociation) is also seen.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection. This is done with darkfield microscopy or immunofluorescence.

Leptospires should be treated with IV penicillin. Ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or doxycycline are alternatives for the treatment of severe leptospirosis.

Other options-

Option A: Albert's stain is used to demonstrate Corynebacteria with metachromatic granules. On staining with Albert stain, it shows delicate green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules. 

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is commonly used for staining fungal cell walls. It stains the fungal wall black.

Option D: Loeffler’s methylene blue is used to stain the granules of Corynebacteria a bluish-purple color.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the mechanism of action of post-coital levonorgestrel pill?

choices.text: It acts by inhibiting or delaying ovulation
It does not disrupt a zygote that has already implanted
It impairs the functioning of corpus luteum
It increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Levonorgestrel (LNG) as post-coital contraception is it does not increase the risk of a subsequent pregnancy being ectopic (Option D). It reduces the absolute risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing pregnancy overall.

The progestin-only method of post-coital contraception consists of a single dose of 1.5mg LNG or two doses of 0.75 mg LNG taken 12 hours apart. It should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected coitus but can be given as late as 120 hours after.

Other methods of emergency contraception:

  • 30 mg ulipristal acetate
  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (Yuzpe method): one dose of 100 μg of Ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG, followed by a second dose of the same, after 12 hours.
  • Cu-containing intrauterine device

The mechanisms of action include:

  • Inhibition or delay in ovulation
  • Endometrial changes causing prevention of implantation
  • Interference with sperm transport or penetration
  • Impaired function of corpus luteum

Pregnancies that develop in spite of emergency hormonal contraception are unaffected and emergency hormonal contraception is not a form of medical abortion. It cannot disrupt a zygote that has already implanted.

Except for the copper IUD, other emergency contraceptive methods do not prevent subsequent pregnancies resulting from intercourse during the same cycle. There is no associated delay in the return of fertility after taking emergency contraceptive pills.

 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of the drugs given for post-operative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonia, not postoperative nausea and vomiting.

The drugs given for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) act by 

  • 5-HT3 antagonism
  • NK-1 antagonism
  • D2 antagonism

The 5- HT3 receptor mediates vomiting and is found in the gastrointestinal tract and the brain (area postrema). 5-HT3 antagonists like ondansetron and granisetron selectively block the serotonin 5-HT3 receptors, with little or no effect on dopamine receptors.

Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, an NK1 antagonist, has been found to reduce PONV perioperatively and is additive with ondansetron for this indication. 

Dopamine receptors, particularly D2 and D3 receptors when activated cause nausea and vomiting. Dopamine antagonists like metoclopramide and droperidol block the dopamine receptors at the chemo-receptor trigger zone, thereby reducing PONV.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient-specific: Female gender, non-smoking status, history of motion sickness/PONV
  • Anesthetic-specific: Nitrous oxide, volatile anesthetics, opioids
  • Surgery-specific: Increased duration of surgery, type of surgery

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine
  • Aprepitant

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

questions.text: The electrocardiogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS complexes, rSR' pattern in lead V1, and a curved S wave which is wider than the R wave in lead V6. This points to a diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB).

To make a diagnosis of RBBB, the following three criteria should be met:

  1. QRS duration >120 ms.
  2. rSR' pattern present in leads V1 or V2. The R' is usually wider than the initial R wave.
  3. S wave of greater duration than the R wave in leads V6.

Bundle branch blocks occur due to a block in the conduction in the right or the left bundle system below the AV node. RBBB is often seen in patients with no underlying heart disease, while left bundle branch block (LBBB) is seen associated with ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and valvular heart disease.

Other options:

Option B: The ECG findings suggestive of LBBB include:

  • QRS duration >120 ms
  • Broad, notched, or slurred R wave in leads V5 or V6
  • Absent q waves in leads V5 or V6
  • QS (no preceding R wave) or rS (small R wave but deep S wave) complexes in lead V1

The image below shows QRS patterns in the right and left bundle branch blocks:

 

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome occurs due to an abnormal conduction pathway in the cardiac tissues between the atria and ventricles. ECG will show the following features:

  • A shortened PR interval 
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex 

The image below shows the delta waves in WPW syndrome

 

Option D: In ventricular bigeminy, every normal QRS complex is followed by a premature ventricular contraction, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital after being involved in a high-speed two-wheeler motor vehicle accident. Blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drips from both nostrils which increases on leaning forward. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. Which of the following can be used to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient experiencing leakage from their nose after suffering from a Le-Fort II fracture is likely to have cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. β-2 transferrin can be used to diagnose this condition. 

β2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.

Beta trace protein is another protein that is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus and is specific for CSF, but testing facilities are not widely available.

Glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation is no longer used.

History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign (central red blood spot and peripheral lighter halo) on a handkerchief/tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Although the beta-2-transferrin assay may confirm the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea, a high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is required to localize the site of the defect causing the CSF leak. 

An intrathecal fluorescein study may be performed preoperatively or intraoperatively to confirm the site of the defect. 

Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi-sitting position. Blowing of nose, sneezing, and straining should be avoided. Prophylactic antibiotics can be administered to prevent meningitis. Persistent cases may be treated surgically by the intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach. Nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which among the following is COVID appropriate behaviour?

choices.text: Maintain a distance of at least 2 feet in all public places
Remove the upper string of the mask first followed by the lower string
Tie the lower string of the mask first followed by upper string
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards

questions.solution:
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards is the only COVID appropriate behaviour in the above options.

 COVID appropriate behaviours prevent the transmission of COVID 19 infection. Important ones are:

  • Greet without physical contact
  • Maintain a distance of at least 6 feet in all public places.
  • Wear reusable hand-made face-cover or mask, at all times.
    • The nasal clip should be present over the nose and external pleats should face downwards. 
    • Open the mask pleats so that the mask covers the mouth and nose. 
    • Tie the upper strings of the mask first followed by lower strings.
    • Do not touch the front of the mask.
    • Replace the mask every 8 hours or when damp.
    • While removing, the mask, remove the lower string of the mask first followed by the upper string.
    • Dispose the mask and wash your hands.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
  • Maintain respiratory hygiene. Cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze with a tissue or handkerchief. If there is no tissue or handkerchief, always cover your nose and mouth with a bent elbow before coughing or sneezing. Immediately wash your hands after that.
  • Wash hands frequently and thoroughly or sanitise with alcohol-based sanitiser.
  • Regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces by wearing gloves.
  • Do not spit in the open
  • Avoid unnecessary travel and discourage crowd and social gatherings.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the graph shown below are true except?

choices.text: The first urge to void is felt at a volume of about 300 mL
The sense of fullness is felt at a volume of about 400 mL
The flatness of segment Ib is due to law of Laplace

questions.solution:
The above graph is a cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and not at 300 mL.

Cystometrogram is a  plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia where an initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib where a long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II where a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R

In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. But as the radius too increases the increase in pressure is slight until the bladder is relatively full. The marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of about 400 mL.

questions.text: A patient who has a history of substance abuse with a semisynthetic opioid is now referred to a rehabilitation center. Which of the following drugs is he likely addicted to?
questions.solution:
He is likely addicted to heroin as it is the only semisynthetic opioid among the given options.

Morphine, codeine, and thebaine are natural opioids derived from poppy Papaver somniferum.

Related Pearl: Classification of Opioids

Naturally Occurring:

  • Morphine
  • Codeine (methyl morphine)
  • Papaverine
  • Thebaine

Semisynthetic:

  • Heroin (diacetyl morphine)
  • Dihydromorphone, morphinone
  • Thebaine derivatives (e.g., etorphine, buprenorphine)

Synthetic:

  • Morphinan series (e.g., levorphanol, butorphanol)
  • Diphenylpropylamine series (e.g., methadone)
  • Benzomorphan series (e.g., pentazocine)
  • Phenylpiperidine series (e.g., meperidine, fentanyl, sufentanil, alfentanil, remifentanil)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Quantiferon-Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT) is correct?

choices.text: It is an ELISA technique that detects TB by using purified mononuclear cells
It is more sensitive for children below the age of 5
It is used as an alternative to tuberculin skin test
It uses molecular probes to detect DNA of TB

questions.solution:
Quantiferon-Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT) is an interferon-gamma release assay which is used as an alternative to the tuberculin skin test.

It is an ELISA technique that detects interferon-gamma in blood.

Other options:

  • T-Spot-TB is another ELISA technique that uses purified peripheral blood mononuclear cells.
  • These techniques should not be used in severely immunocompromised individuals and children less than 5 years of age.
  • GeneXpert MTB/RIF (Nucleic acid amplification tests) test is used for rapid detection of M tuberculosis in specimen through DNA detection.

questions.text: What percentage of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel should be occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque to call it a stage of critical stenosis?
questions.solution:
70 - 75% of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel is occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque in the stage of critical stenosis.

In atherosclerotic stenosis, critical stenosis is the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This typically occurs when the occlusion produces a 70% to 75% decrease in luminal cross-sectional area. With this degree of stenosis in the coronary circulation, the patient may experience chest pain on exertion i.e, stable angina.

Critical stenosis also leads to bowel ischemia, intermittent claudication, mesenteric occlusion, sudden cardiac death, chronic ischemic heart disease and ischemic encephalopathy.

An increased level of LDL is directly associated with the development of coronary heart disease. This promotes the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, undergoing the following process.


An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as rupture, ulceration, erosion which lead to thrombus formation, or hemorrhage into the plaque which increases the plaque size. Both of these consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply.

questions.text: A randomized control study was conducted on 100 people to determine the causes and effects of different hormones that increase insulin secretion. All of the following factors increase insulin secretion except?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin decreases insulin secretion. Acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), and arginine stimulate its release.

Somatostatin, also known as growth hormone-inhibitory hormone, is secreted by the delta cells of the islets of Langerhans. It acts locally to inhibit insulin and glucagon secretion, reducing tissue utilization of absorbed nutrients. The primary function of somatostatin is to prevent the rapid depletion of nutrients, ensuring their availability over an extended period.

Insulin, secreted by the pancreatic beta cells, responds to increased blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake, storage, and utilization. When blood glucose levels rise, insulin:

  • Enhances hepatic uptake of glucose, storing it as glycogen
  • Facilitates the conversion of excess glucose into fatty acids
  • Suppresses glycogen breakdown to maintain glucose homeostasis

Conversely, when blood glucose levels fall, insulin secretion decreases, activating phosphorylase to break down glycogen and release stored glucose into circulation.

Mechanism of Insulin Secretion

  1. Glucose Entry: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells via GLUT-2 receptors.
  2. Phosphorylation: Inside the cell, glucokinase (rate-limiting enzyme) phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which is then oxidized to generate ATP.
  3. Potassium Channel Closure: Increased ATP levels close ATP-sensitive potassium channels, leading to cell depolarization.
  4. Calcium Influx: Depolarization triggers the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels, causing Ca²⁺ influx.
  5. Insulin Release: Elevated intracellular Ca²⁺ levels stimulate the exocytosis of insulin-containing vesicles, releasing insulin into the bloodstream.

Other Options:

Option B: Acetylcholine stimulates M3 receptors, which increases Ca²⁺ , which leads to increased insulin. Hence, Acetylcholine promotes insulin secretion during the cephalic phase of digestion (before food intake).

Option C: GIP is an incretin hormone K-cells release in the small intestine in response to oral glucose intake. It binds to β-cell receptors and increases cAMP, which enhances insulin secretion.

Option D: Arginine is an amino acid that stimulates β-cells directly.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. What is the best plan of management in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging. Chemotherapy with radiation is the best plan of management in this case.

Note: If the patient just had carcinoma extension up to the pelvic wall and/or the presence of hydronephrosis, it would have been classified as Stage IIIB.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text:
A patient with lung cancer on treatment for the past few months now presents with a mild headache, confusion, vomiting, and 2 episodes of convulsions. CT scan of the head appears normal. Laboratory investigations reveal hyponatremia and increased osmolarity of the urine. Which of the following drugs can be used in the management of this patient?
  1. Hypertonic saline
  2. Conivaptan
  3. Demeclocycline
  4. Fludrocortisone
  5. Desmopressin
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). Options 1,2,3, and 4 i.e. hypertonic saline, conivaptan, demeclocycline, and fludrocortisone can be used in the management of this condition. 

SIADH can occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome to cancers of the lung. Inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion can occur due to ectopic production of the hormone, or increased release of the hormone, or increased administration of the hormone. This occurs in carcinomas of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovaries, bladder and ureter. It is also seen in head trauma and infections like pneumonia, bacterial or viral, abscess (lung, or brain), cavitation (aspergillosis) and Tuberculosis.

Drugs that cause SIADH include vasopressin or desmopressin (5), serotonin reuptake inhibitors, oxytocin (high dose), vincristine, carbamazepine and nicotine. 

Increased anti-diuretic hormone results in the retention of water within the body causing dilution of the body fluids. Patients usually present with features of water intoxication. They include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, convulsions, and hyponatremia.

Treatment includes correction of sodium levels using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are AVP receptor-2 (arginine-vasopressin) antagonists. They block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Symptomatic intrauterine adhesions (also termed uterine synechiae) are known as Asherman syndrome. This condition occurs when the uterine cavity is obliterated by scarring due to filmy adhesions, dense bands. Endometrial damage can occur after curettage, infection due to an intrauterine device, uterine surgery, or rarely tuberculous endometritis. 

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions.

questions.text: Encephalopathy and Non-Convulsive Status Epilepticus(NCSE) have been reported with the use of ______.
questions.solution:
Encephalopathy and Non-Convulsive Status Epilepticus(NCSE) have been reported with the use of cefepime. 

The mechanism of neurotoxicity in cephalosporin therapy involves inhibiting GABA-A release, increasing glutamate levels, and inducing the release of endotoxins and TNF-alpha, which is involved in septic encephalopathy.

 Nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) refers to a prolonged seizure that manifests primarily as altered mental status as opposed to the dramatic convulsions seen in generalized tonic-clonic status epilepticus.

There are 2 main types of NCSE, each of which has a different presentation, cause, and expected outcome

  • In the first type of NCSE, patients present with confusion or abnormal behavior, suggesting the diagnosis of absence status epilepticus (ASE) or complex partial status epilepticus (CPSE).
  • The second type of NCSE (subtle status epilepticus [SSE]) must be considered in comatose patients who present after a prolonged generalized tonic-clonic seizure and who may have only subtle motor manifestations of a seizure, such as facial or hand twitchings.
  • Whereas the morbidity and mortality in patients with prolonged ASE or CPSE is low, the mortality associated with SSE can exceed 30% if the seizure duration is greater than 60 minutes

Note: The FDA has approved the use of cefepime-enmetazobactam which is a combination of a fourth-generation cephalosporin and beta-lactamase inhibitor for use in complicated UTIs (including pyelonephritis).

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with difficult delivery for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. Name the condition for which this maneuver is performed.
questions.solution:
The image depicts McRoberts maneuver, which is performed in case of shoulder dystocia

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing the delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia is as follows: 

  • First line: 
    • McRoberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of the thigh)
  • Second line:
    • Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion) 
  • Third line:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (Push the head back and do a cesarean)
    • Cleidotomy (#clavicle of the baby)
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of the mother)

Other maneuvers: Rubin, gaskin (mother on all four limbs), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

The image below illustrates the McRoberts maneuver.

 

The image below illustrates cleidotomy being performed: 

 

The image below illustrates Zavanelli maneuver. Here, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. 

Note:

  • In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli maneuver.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

questions.text: Mr. Somu presents with complaints of severe heartburn for the past few months. You prescribe him omeprazole and send him home. However, he visits again after a month saying that the symptoms have improved slightly but have not completely settled. You perform a rapid urease test and it is found to be positive. Which of the following combination of drugs will you prescribe to Mr. Somu? (PPI- Proton pump inhibitors)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has a peptic ulcer disease due to the underlying infection with Helicobacter pylori. It should be treated by a combination of clarithromycin + amoxicillin + PPI for 14 days.

Important combinations used in the management of H. pylori infections are

  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPI) + clarithromycin 500mg + amoxicillin 1g or metronidazole 500mg tid - for 14 days
  • PPI + Bismuth subcitrate 120-300mg or subsalicylate 300mg + tetracycline 500mg + metronidazole 250-500mg for 10- 14 days
  • PPI + clarithromycin 500mg + amoxicillin 1g + nitroimidazole 500mg for 10- 14 days
  • PPI + amoxicillin 1g + levofloxacin 500mg or 5-7 days

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative rod and contain flagella. It is a risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. It causes gastric injury by releasing various virulence factors like γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), cytotoxin-associated gene A (cagA) product, virulence components vacuolating toxin (vacA), and lipopolysaccharides.

Important tests for the detection of H.Pylori are:

  • Rapid urease test
  • Histology
  • Culture
  • Serology
  • Urea breath test
  • Stool antigen test

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient had a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He is a known hypertensive patient for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. Acute coronary syndrome was ruled and he is hemodynamically stable. Considering aortic dissection, which is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
CT is the initial investigation for aortic dissection. As it is more widely available and takes a shorter time compared to MRI.

MRI, though highly accurate for acute aortic disease evaluation, is usually confined to cases of severe renal insufficiency or absolute contraindications to iodinated contrast medium.

Ultrasound and aortography are not the investigation of choice for aortic dissection. Aortography used to be the gold standard. It involved the injection of high-flow contrast into the vessel. It has been replaced by noninvasive imaging. Intravascular ultrasound can be performed, but the procedure is expensive and requires experience.

The below image depicts a CT chest indicating Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. (A) Axial view and (B) sagittal view. Arrows indicate intimal flap.

The Stanford classification of aortic dissection is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved:

  • Type A: affects ascending aorta and arch:
    • Requires urgent surgical management
  • Type B: begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels:
    • Dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery
    • Medical management with blood pressure control

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

questions.text: A young woman was admitted for ingestion of several acetaminophen tablets. After 2 weeks of admission, she developed disturbed sleep and mild confusion. Investigations revealed deranged prothrombin time and bleeding time. The resident wanted to assess the requirement of liver transplantation using the King's College Hospital criteria. All of the following parameters are required to evaluate this patient except?
questions.solution:
King's college hospital criteria for paracetamol overdose does not include age < 10 or > 40 years. This parameter is included in the non paracetamol cases of liver failure.

King's college hospital criteria is a selection criterion in acute liver failure for liver transplantation. It includes the following parameters:

Liver transplantation is indicated in acetaminophen-induced ALF if there is a presence of

  • Either pH <7.3
  • Or all of the following
    • Prothrombin time >100 sec
    • Serum creatinine level >3.4 mg/dL (300 μmol/L)
    • Grade 3-4 encephalopathy

Liver transplantation is indicated in nonacetaminophen causes of ALF if there is a presence of 

  • Either prothrombin time >100 sec
  • Or any three of the following
    • Jaundice to encephalopathy time > 7 days
    • Age < 10 or > 40 years
    • Indeterminate or drug-induced causes
    • Bilirubin > 300 μmol/L (>3.4 mg/dL)
    • Prothrombin time > 50 secs
  • Or Factor V level < 15% and encephalopathy grade 3 or 4

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is sensed via which type of receptor?
questions.solution:
The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is Umami. Umami tastes are sensed by the activation of G-protein coupled receptors.

Taste Receptors: Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter, and umami. The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:

  • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC →salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2, T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) or T1R1, T1R3 families → Umami

L-glutamate was identified as having a unique taste, that cannot be categorized as bitter, sweet, salty, and sour. Therefore, it was called umami, with the Japanese word "umai" meaning "delicious". Ribonucleotides such as inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine-5'-monophosphate (GMP), elicit umami taste on their own. It wasn't until the identification of G protein-coupled receptors specific for glutamate taste, that umami was completely accepted as a unique taste.

Sweet G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Umami Glutamate receptor family (mGluR4) and G-protein coulped receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Bitter G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T2R family
Sour H+ movement through ENaC

questions.text: A 35-year-old soccer player presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the left ear following trauma to the ear a few days back. On examination, his left ear feels warm, slightly tender to touch, and firm.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the image depicting a red pinna is suggestive of perichondritis.

A common cause of perichondritis is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or noniatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated.

Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium.

Treatment in the early stages consists of:

  • Systemic antibiotics
  • 4% aluminum acetate compresses
  • Prompt drainage of the abscess and culture and sensitivity of the pus.
  • Occasionally, a catheter is placed in the abscess with a continuous drip of antibiotics

Other options:

Option A- Cauliflower ear is also known as perichondrial hematoma or boxer's ear. It is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma that occurs due to the collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and the perichondrium. It may get infected leading to severe perichondritis. It is treated by aspirating the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing. Prophylactic antibiotics should be given. 

Cauliflower ear is shown in the image below.


Option C- Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis refers to small, nodular, tender lesions occurring on the helix of the ear. Treatment involves the excision of the nodule with its skin and cartilage.


Option D - Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC.

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage. Marcus Gunn pupil also known as relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease as seen in optic nerve neuritis or primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG).

RAPD is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye.

It is diagnosed by the swinging flashlight test where the flashlight is swung to and fro, and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils constrict when any one eye is stimulated (due to direct and consensual light reflex). In the presence of RAPD, both pupils will abnormally dilate when the affected eye is stimulated. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil. 

Causes of RAPD:

  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)
  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )

Other options:

Option B: Adie tonic pupil is a unilateral dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor nerve supply damage. In these patients the light reflex is absent and the accomdation (near) reflex is sluggish. It is commonly seen in young females and is associated with absent knee jerk.

Option C: Argyll Robertson pupils are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It is commonly seen in patients with neurosyphilis. In these patients the pupillary reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present (ARP).

Option D: Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

questions.text:
You are a final-year student attending the surgery practical examination. The examiner asks you to examine the axillary lymph nodes of a patient and to explain the levels of axillary lymph nodes. Match the following axillary lymph nodes and their levels:

1) Anterior group               a) Level 1

2) Central group                b) Level 2

3) Lateral group                 c) Level 3

4) Apical group
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-a,2-b,3-a,4-c.

Axillary lymph nodes are divided into levels 1-3 on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

Level I: (Lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Lateral: along the axillary vein - drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group): along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast.(1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group): along the subscapular vessels

Level II: (Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Central: embedded in fat in the center of the axilla- receive drainage from Level I groups

Level III: (Lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group): which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other axillary groups and drains into subclavian lymphatic trunk.

Interpectoral (Rotters node) - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.(Level II)

 

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

Failure of  fusion of the paramesonephric duct
Two ureteric buds arising from mesonephric duct
Persistence of the posterior cardinal vein

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a right-sided fish hook ureter are suggestive of the retrocaval ureter, and it is due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein.

The circumcaval ureter, or retrocaval ureter, is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). This congenital abnormality occurs due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein, and the ureter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava. The anomaly always appears on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

This condition occurs in 1 in 1500 individuals. Most commonly, it does not produce any clinical manifestations, but rarely, it can cause upper ureteric obstruction. Even though it is a congenital anomaly, the clinical manifestations are not seen until 3rd and 4th decades of life. The clinical manifestations are a result of right-sided hydronephrosis, which can be due to kinking of the ureter, an adynamic ureteric segment, or compression of the ureter against the psoas muscle.

The classical appearance of the retrocaval ureter is termed a fish-hook ureter. As the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

Other options:

Option A: Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadias, a condition in which abnormal openings of the urethra occur along the ventral aspect of the penis.

Option B: Failure of fusion of the paramesonephric duct produces duplication of the uterus(e.g., Uterus didelphys, bicornuate uterus, etc.)

Option C: Two ureteric buds arising from the mesonephric duct lead to duplex ureters.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OP with painful genital ulcers. Gram staining revealed gram-negative coccobacilli as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a suitable culture medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painful genital ulcer with gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in parallel chains is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the suitable culture medium of Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid or soft sore is a venereal disease characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia. This infection remains localized, spreading only to the regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance.

On chocolate agar, enriched with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum, and containing vancomycin as a selective agent, H.ducreyi forms small, grey translucent colonies after incubation at 35°C under 10% CO and 2 high humidity in 2-8 days.

H.ducreyi requires X factor, but not V factor for growth. H.influenzae requires X and V factor for growth.

Note: Fish in-stream appearance is seen in Vibrio cholera.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient has to undergo incisional hernia surgery under general anesthesia. She complains of awareness in her past caesarean section. Which of the following monitoring techniques can be used to prevent such awareness?
questions.solution:
The monitoring technique used to prevent such an awareness intraoperatively is the bispectral index. 

The bispectral index is a monitoring technique to check the depth of anesthesia using an algorithm by a device. Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated. It utilizes parameters like EEG signals, eye blinking, etc. 

BIS examines four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

  1. Low-frequency waves (as found during deep anesthesia)
  2. High-frequency beta activation (as found during light anesthesia)
  3. Suppressed EEG waves
  4. Burst suppression

It has numerical values from 0 to 100. with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia: 40-60.

value		    Interpretation
     80-100    Awake
     60-80   Moderate sedation
     40-60 General anesthesia

questions.text: The PAGE DNA electrophoresis of the affected cell shows a smear pattern. Additionally, Annexin V is negative. Which of the following is a true statement about this type of cell death?

choices.text: It can be physiological or pathological

questions.solution:
The cell death discussed here is necrosis. Karyolysis is seen in necrosis.

Pyknosis followed by karyorrhexis and karyolysis is the pattern of nuclear changes observed in necrosis.

Other options:

Option A: Apoptosis is genetically programmed
Option B: Apoptosis can be physiological or pathological. Necrosis is always pathological.
Option C: Apoptosis has an intact plasma membrane. In necrosis, plasma membrane is disrupted.

questions.text: A gynecologist is performing the following procedure in a woman with postmenopausal bleeding. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The image depicts saline infusion sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography. It is usually done after a transvaginal ultrasound, to assess the detailed anatomy of the uterine cavity.

In this procedure, a balloon catheter is inserted through the cervix and the endometrial cavity is distended with 20-40ml of sterile saline. The balloon is inflated to block the backflow of the infused sterile saline and transvaginal ultrasound is performed to visualize the cavity. 

It is used:

  • To determine the endometrial thickness 
  • To determine the cause in cases of infertility
  • To identify Mullerian anomalies 
  • To visualize endometrial polyps and pedunculated fibroids

The image given below shows the appearance of the uterus on SIS.

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasound is the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding.

Option B: In balloon endometrial ablation, a balloon is inserted into the uterus and inflated with glycine or 5% glucose. It is then heated up, and the endometrium is ablated by the tamponade effect.

Option D: In hysterosalpingography, contrast dye is inserted into the uterus via a catheter, and the uterine and fallopian tube anatomy is visualized.
